TEXT: Expressing Needs Children who have their physical needs met are more motivated to explore and learn new things. Play-acting is one way to help them develop the language to express their needs by modeling situations and solutions.

Poetry The special thing about poetry is that teachers often read poems aloud, repeat them often, and share them in groups. When children listen to poems being read, they strengthen listening skills. They attend to the words and think about what those words mean together.

Vocabulary Development Language and vocabulary are the foundation of learning to read and write. Children who develop strong oral language skills and vocabulary in their early years will be successful in kindergarten and first grade.
Mind Builder Children use problem-solving skills continually without knowing it—while experimenting, investigating, selecting materials, and working together (ECMHC.org/Social-Emotional).

Vocabulary Development Learning new vocabulary words is key to a preschool child's academic preparation for kindergarten. Children's vocabulary grows significantly when vocabulary instruction is introduced in read-aloud books. Promote children's vocabulary development by identifying suitable vocabulary for explicit instruction during story time.

Mind Builder Flexible thinking involves thinking about something in a different way and taking a different approach to a task or a problem. It plays an important role in problem solving. Encourage flexible thinking by playing silly rhyming or pun games, inviting children to suggest different uses for everyday objects, or making a new game by changing the rules of a popular game (Harvard College, 2019).

Multilingual Learners Making cross-text connections helps all children explore the information contained in a book plus the big ideas carried across texts. Multilingual learners can benefit from frequent access to pictures and other media that cover concepts in the story being read aloud in English.

Self-Awareness Preschool children become increasingly aware of their bodies, feelings, thoughts, and abilities. They begin to ask, "Who am I?" This awareness is crucial to developing self-control and social skills. Encourage this growing awareness by reading aloud books about self-awareness and by encouraging children's competence.

Classroom Environment Keeping a few mementos in the classroom can help children transition from home to preK. Familiar items, like family photos or a favorite book, can help make a new place seem less overwhelming. Reviewing the schedule every morning and posting a visual schedule will also help children feel more comfortable.

Mind Builder Help boost children's awareness by helping them get to know one another. Have children introduce themselves and say their name and age. Ask each child to think of something else that is special about themselves and makes them feel proud, and have them share that as well. This will help children practice showing awareness and expressing pride in themselves in age-appropriate ways (Bredekamp, 2009).

Healthy Choices Help children understand that many activities they enjoy are also good for their bodies. Both active movement and mental stimulation promote good health. Extend the discussion to include other healthy choices, such as eating healthily and getting enough sleep.

Counting Some children might already be able to count. Others might not yet know their numbers. Approach this skill with purpose, planning, and playfulness. Build on children’s current understanding and develop their readiness through fun activities.

Counting and Cardinality To engage with children’s counting readiness, encourage children to use one-to-one correspondence, counting, and cardinality throughout their day. Children are naturally very curious, and asking them to count how many friends, toys, snacks, or pencils they have improves their numerical understandings.

Mind Builder Describe an exciting or stressful situation and give examples and nonexamples of appropriate reactions. Practice typical preK scenarios in controlled situations in the classroom so that children are more successful when these situations actually occur. Emphasize that children control their own behavior, even when they have strong feelings (Murphy, 2019).

Multilingual Learners Children with different home languages or cultures might know how to count proficiently in that language. Help them learn the English numbers by pointing to the corresponding Number Card or Magnetic Number as you say the number word. Encourage children to repeat the numbers after you to become more familiar with the English words.

Naming Feelings Preschoolers often experience their emotions physically. They clench their fists when angry or feel a knot in their stomach when sad. But they often don’t know yet how to label these feelings. Guide children to connect physical reactions with the feelings behind them by naming each feeling directly. Knowing what an emotion is can make it less scary to feel!

Counting and Cardinal Numbers To help children become more proficient at counting, incorporate fun counting activities into the daily routine. Encourage children to count as they hand out pencils to friends, take steps to the bathroom, or swing on the playground. Encourage them to use their fingers for support when helpful.

Working Memory Children can practice enhancing their working memory and sustaining their attention by comparing numbers and measurements. Children will need to hold information about each set in their minds as they think about and compare sets.

Mind Builder Children need to remember steps to solve a problem or complete a task. When presenting a multistep task, you might want to provide ways to help them remember each step. For example, there might be a hand motion associated with each subtask, or you could chant the steps rhythmically to boost retention (Diamond, 2007).

Multilingual Learners Some multilingual learners might not feel comfortable speaking the academic language required by school subjects. When discussing measurement terms, which are necessary for both math and science instruction, provide concrete examples and explain measurement terms in the child’s first language.

Your Family and You Each family is unique and is made up of different members. Families can build a sense of belonging and security. One of the guiding principles for school readiness is that learning occurs within the context of relationships, both at home and at school. These interactions are essential to children’s learning.

Observations The ability to compare numbers and understand measurements begins with making observations. A child may notice that her brother is short and her sister is tall. A child could have more aunts than uncles. As children grow older, they make increasingly complex observations and include greater detail in their descriptions.

Counting Children naturally use ordinal numbers to describe line order, turn-taking, and other daily routines and behaviors. Help children learn ordinal numbers by teaching them in the context of their lives. When children are lined up to leave the classroom, ask them to identify who is first, second, third, fourth, and fifth in line.

Mind Builder Help children learn to make and keep relationships with peers and trusted adults. Guide children to cultivate these relationships by calling friends and adults by name, learning about their lives, and noticing when they are absent. One practical application of this Mind Builder skill is to help children plan something special for a parent’s or friend’s birthday.

Multilingual Learners Children’s school schedules and daily activities vary widely by country. In France and China, for example, children go home to eat lunch with their families and then return for the afternoon. Encourage an appreciation of other countries’ cultures by sharing information about schools around the world.

School Rules Share some reasons with children why schools have rules. Help children understand that schools and classrooms use rules to keep children safe, healthy, and happy. Effective rules promote learning and allow children to grow and experiment in a safe space.

Understanding the Passage of Time Preschool children are still learning the concept of time. They don’t think of a day as something that passes in hours and minutes. Instead, they mark time by events. It is important at this age to develop and discuss routines wherever possible. A routine gives children a way to talk about and predict each day more easily.

Geometry Although many children begin to learn shapes before preschool, they may not realize that they already find shapes every day. Recognizing shapes in familiar contexts helps provide children with a foundational understanding of conceptual geometry and prepares them to draw and use shapes themselves.

Mind Builder Symbolic thinking, or using one thing to stand for something else, is an important skill for preschoolers. Thinking symbolically is what allows us to represent people with dolls and real-world scenes with drawings. As you read aloud, point out to children that illustrations in books often depict familiar real-world objects and scenes, even when they don't "look like photographs" (Bredekamp, 2007).

Multilingual Learners Young children often learn new words incidentally, through conversations, books, and listening to others. Shape names, however, are used relatively infrequently and need to be taught explicitly. Increase children’s exposure to these words by frequently pointing out shapes in context and naming them.

Geography For preschoolers, geography is about more than recognizing the buildings and natural features they see. When young children build awareness of the world around them, they start to develop a sense of connectedness to the place where they live. This connectedness, commonly called sense of place, is crucial for social-emotional health.

Creating Art Creating art is an important part of young children’s development. Drawing teaches fine motor skills, math skills such as understanding size and shapes, and cognitive skills such as planning and cause and effect. Free expression is particularly important as a healthy outlet.

Vocabulary Development Children likely know the word doctor, but not physician. Tell children that there is sometimes more than one word to describe the same thing, like doctor and physician. Help children name synonyms for other careers, like cook and chef, architect and building designer, or news reporter and journalist.

Mind Builder There are many opportunities for preschool children to take care of shared objects and complete jobs for the benefit of the community. Children do this daily when they participate in clean up, volunteer for classroom jobs, and handle communal materials with care. Point out examples of children helping the community during the day to explain this Mind Builder skill.

Measurement Children naturally think about measurement as they play, from wondering how much water a cup can hold before overflowing to deciding which doll is taller than the other. Satisfy their natural curiosity by offering activities that allow children to measure using standard and nonstandard measuring tools.

Measurement Discuss measurement while preparing foods as a group, encouraging children to use measurement terms and comparison vocabulary. Snack time is a natural time to teach children phrases for comparing amounts (more than, less than, the same as) and terms to describe attributes (long, short, heavy, light, large, small).

Spatial Sense Children develop a sense of spatial relationships early on and they use perceptual information to guide their own motions and interactions. Encourage children to describe the position of classmates or items using location words and phrases so that they can start to describe how they interact with their environment.

Mind Builder When classifying, children may instinctively recognize the similarities or differences between items without being able to verbalize them. Help children understand the idea of sorting by attribute, or category, by sorting and re-sorting a small set of items. First sort by one attribute, like color, size, or shape, and then re-sort the same set by a different attribute.

Multisyllabic Words Children might want to use words that they find difficult to pronounce. When children use multisyllabic words encountered in texts, it may take practice to say the words completely and correctly. Set aside a few minutes to help children practice correct pronunciation of challenging words.

Shapes One way children classify objects at an early age is by identifying their shapes. At first, they simply recognize and identify the shape. As children's understanding of geometry develops, they learn to recognize shapes in various positions and sizes. Children also develop the language skills to identify the characteristics of each shape.

Multilingual Learners Children from different cultures and with different home languages may have different ways to make the sounds for animals and vehicles. Encourage children to share and compare animal and vehicle sounds. Comparing these sounds provides an opportunity for children to share an aspect of their home languages with the class.

Mind Builder Making and keeping relationships is an important part of social development and one that you should focus on throughout the year. Children can learn to engage in strong, trusting relationships with you and other adults in their lives as well as with their classmates. It's important to use activities during the day that will help children develop empathy for others (Boyarshinov/frogstreet.com).

Listening Listening and remembering are the first building blocks to comprehension and literacy among young children. Make sure that children are paying attention to what you and others say when you are together. Reading aloud daily gets children interested in the characters' stories as well as their own stories and the stories of others.

Mind Builder Being able to identify emotions in others is a critical part of children's emotional development. The more children listen to stories you read aloud, the more they will start to understand that other people have perspectives and feelings different from their own. Provide as many opportunities as you can to help children identify other people's feelings.

Social Studies Emphasize the importance of accepting and respecting the differences between people from different parts of the world—different names, different foods, different traditions. This will help children develop empathy as well as increase social awareness.

Social-Emotional Development It's easy to monitor the physical development of children at this age, as we see them getting taller, bigger, and stronger before our eyes. It takes more work to assess their social-emotional development, but it's important to do so. Take special note of children's understanding of feelings, both in themselves and in others.

Mind Builder Learning to identify all feelings in a positive way helps children to nurture the skills they need to become healthy and well-adjusted children and adults. Learning to identify the feelings of others not only gives children a better understanding of their own emotions but also helps them to develop empathy and build stronger friendships (kidshelpline.com.au/Understanding Feelings).

Multilingual Learners While multilingual learners may be struggling with English, the emotions human beings feel are universal. Examining them together can create entry points into topics that would otherwise be too difficult. At the same time, it's important to be sensitive to cultural differences and emotional cues that may vary among different groups.

Vocabulary Development The highest rate of vocabulary development occurs during the preschool years. While feelings have a strong nonverbal component, young children must learn the words to talk about their feelings with competence and compassion.

Healthy Habits Just as physical exercise and nutrition are important parts of a healthy lifestyle for young children, so is learning how to access, understand, and self-regulate their feelings. Developing a healthy relationship with their feelings will serve children for many years to come.

Social-Emotional Development Young children need plenty of opportunities to practice social and emotional skills in the classroom, at play, and at home. You will have opportunities to gauge children's social-emotional skills as they interact with you and other children. Note which areas of interaction require more awareness.

Mind Builder Developing a healthy imagination is a key motivation and creativity skill that enables children to engage with the world in meaningful ways. As you discuss relationships among families and friends in stories you read, encourage children to use their imaginations to creatively problem-solve a range of scenarios (Hermes/healthfully.com, August 13, 2019).

Multilingual Learners Increasingly diverse classrooms work to create a safe, nurturing environment. Sharing diverse read-aloud books will help children benefit from exposure to other languages and cultures. When encountering words that are from a culture that is unfamilar to children, invite them to share some corresponding words from their home language.

Executive Function Self-regulation is an important executive function that children must master in order to do well in school and in life. Take advantage of opportunities this week to manage children's expectations and frustrations as they work with this theme ("How Can We Help Kids with Self-Regulation?", n.d.).

Cross-Text Connections For preschoolers, reading comes alive when they see how the ideas and themes in a read-aloud connect to other books and to their own lives. Make sure other books about families are available to children as they continue to explore this fascinating topic. Use it as a springboard to look at their developing sense of self.

Learning Opportunities As you read and reread wonderful books with children, you can look for layered learning opportunities.For example, in a book about friendship, you may also find valuable information about about science or social studies topics. As appropriate, consider diving deeper to follow children's interests and spark a love of learning.

Mind Builder Initiating and joining in play are key social development skills for young children. While playing, children learn important skills that they will continue to use for the rest of their lives: problem solving, creativity, and a willingness to take risks, among others. Helping children learn the language for initiating and joining in play sets them up for success (Pathways.org/Six Stages).

Multilingual Learners Words that share the same morphology or root are known as cognates. For example, the English word delicious and the Spanish word delicioso are cognates. Giving multilingual learners the opportunity to recognize and talk about cognates helps strengthen their skills in both languages.

Social-Emotional Development It's important for young children to feel secure, valued, and cared about. Focusing their attention on how friendships develop among fictional characters as well as in their actual lives will play a vital role during this critical period of social-emotional growth.

Gross Motor Skills Young children should spend hours every day in active play to help them develop strong bodies. Encourage children to move their bodies, using both larger movements as they interact with other children as well as smaller movements during read-alouds, songs, and indoor activities.

Multilingual Learners Young children who are learning more than one language reap many long-term cognitive and social benefits. Create a learning environment where children can use both English and their home language. Let parents know that the use of another language will not inhibit their children's growth in English.

Mind Builder Self-awareness is a skill that will help children learn about themselves and their feelings. The preschool experience includes many challenging words and phrases to convey feelings. Use feeling words like proud andfrustrated to help children recognize their own feelings (Understood.org/Self-Awareness/Importance).

Engaging Children in Conversations Extend conversations by asking questions about what children are doing ("What are you working on?"), asking for explanations ("How do you think that happened?"), asking children to make predictions ('What do you think will happen next?"), and asking children to connect learning to their own lives ("How did you do that?").

Multilingual Learners Encourage children to describe what they see in the classroom. The preschool environment may represent multilingual learners' first unknown social environment. They may have difficulty communicating, following directions, and expressing ideas and feelings. Encouraging children to share what they see will foster free conversation.

Retelling a Story Learning to retell a story is a skill that will help preschoolers with later reading comprehension. Ask children to talk about what happened in the story, the characters, what the characters said and did, and the places where they went. Children can retell a story through drawing. Children can draw a picture about something from the story.

Multilingual Learners What children learn in one language will transfer to other languages naturally. For example, once children learn about community in their home language, they don't need to relearn the same concepts in English. They simply need to learn the corresponding vocabulary in English.

Mind Builder Acquiring the skill of flexible thinking enables us to apply different rules in different situations. We use flexible thinking when we try a new food, go to a new place, categorize things in a new way, and more. We aren't born with this skill, but we all have the ability to practice and improve at any stage of life! Tis is something to share with families as they help their preschooler expand their responses to with new and unfamiliar situations (Parenttoolkit.com/Pre-K/Self-Awareness).

Same and Different Preschool children can understand how objects are the same or different. Begin with concrete things. For example, point out if several children are wearing the same color shirt. Then point out different shirt colors. Eventually you will be able to compare more abstract concepts such as interests.

Scientific Inquiry Encourage children's curiosity about the natural world by creating an environment that celebrates curiosity, observation, and inquiry. Encourage children to observe, ask questions, draw, and discuss what they see. Focus on what children can observe directly and on plants and animals in the environment in which they live.

Comprehension Strategies Books with repetition and rhyme are great opportunities to help children learn to make predictions. They help children gain practice in using comprehension strategies, including listen and remember, use background knowledge, make an inference, make a connection, draw a smart conclusion, and ask questions.

Mind Builder In preschool, children start to realize that we each have different feelings and experiences. They start to care about others, yet they may continue to confuse their own feelings with those of others. You can help by talking about your feelings and the feelings of characters in books (Clark/speechandlanguagekids.com, 2019).

Comparing and Contrasting Preschool children learn social studies concepts by observing and discussing their surroundings: homes, banks, libraries, fire stations, playgrounds, parks, and stores. Encourage children to compare their neighborhood to those in books, taking note of similarities and differences.

Sophisticated Vocabulary One of the key predictors of children's academic achievement is their vocabulary. Developing knowledge of sophisticated words in preschool is critical to a child's success in school and in life. Children love learning "big words." Using words like delectable, scrumptious, and exclaimed will build a strong foundation for life.

Dealing with Disappointment Learning to deal with disappointment helps children develop coping skills and emotional resilience. You can help children by labeling your own emotions (e.g., when you feel frustrated or tired) and by helping children identify and describe their own emotions. Teach children to take deep breaths when they are feeling sad or disappointed.

Mind Builder You can teach children to recognize their own perspective and the perspective of others by emphasizing how a character feels in read aloud texts. Help children learn to recognize a character's perspective, or how he thinks and feels, and compare it to their own perspective (Weis/fortheloveofteachers.com, 2017).

Multilingual Learners Help children learn words to express their feelings in English by modeling words such as disappointed, comfortable, relaxed, happy, unhappy, worried, confused, embarrassed, and ashamed. Multilingual preschoolers are learning these words in their home language, too.

Vocabulary Development Preschool children use their senses to explore materials, positions, and motion. They need vocabulary to express their discoveries about nature, motion, weather, energy, and the environment. Encourage scientific language as they participate in class discussions.

Mind Builder Asking and answering questions are key executive function skills used to learn and share when communicating with others. We practice this skill when we ask who, what, when, why, where, and how questions. We also use it when we ask follow-up questions related to an original question (Ed.gov/Early Learning/Talk Read Sing).

Multilingual Learners Introducing children to different words that describe how things taste, smell, look, sound, and feel is a great opportunity to expand their English vocabulary. Children might already know some concepts, like saltiness, in their home language, and simply need an English label. Concepts such as bitterness may represent an altogether new awareness.

Diagrams The ability to understand the meaning of graphic images is a developmental skill for preschool children. Be prepared to support differing levels of ability to see the purpose and meaning in arrows, circles, and other signs and symbols used in diagrams. This is a valuable skill that will benefit children as they move toward literacy.

Vocabulary Development A child's vocabulary in kindergarten is the biggest predictor of that child's ability to read on or above grade level by Grade 3. Repetition of vocabulary and hearing words in a variety of contexts are vital to children internalizing words. Keep a list of previously taught vocabulary, and find opportunities each day to revisit some of those words.

Social-Emotional Development One of the milestones in children's social-emotional development at this age is their increasing awareness of self as distinct from others. The concerns and insecurities of story characters about themselves in comparison with others will engage children in interesting discussions about differences.

Mind Builder It's important from a very early age to help children set goals and figure out how to meet them. This can help them develop a positive, can-do attitude for the rest of their lives. Encourage even the youngest children to think of a small goal they want to accomplish and figure out the steps they need to take to achieve it (Parents.com/Goal Setting).

Developing Empathy A child's capacity for empathy begins very early in life. Empathetic children are far more likely to engage in positive social behaviors. Helping kids make connections to the experiences of characters—even animals or other nonhuman characters—will help to get them on the path to empathizing with their peers, now and for years to come.

Gross Motor Skills Preschool children need to develop their gross motor skills so they can engage in age-appropriate physical activities and participate in activities that require body control. Children will begin to recognize various measurement scenarios, and incorporate concepts such as long and short into their movement repertoire.

Mind Builder Children are naturally curious. They like to ask questions as they try to understand the world around them. You can encourage this behavior by providing plenty of opportunities for them to inquire about what they see. Learning how to ask and answer questions will build skills that will last a lifetime (Preschoolsteam.com/Inquiry Thinking).

Measuring Skills and Vocabulary Development Young children apply early concepts of measurement in many of their everyday activities. They begin to develop a vocabulary for measurement and comparison. As you begin to introduce measurement terms, focus on words such as long and short, big and small, to make sure children build a working knowledge of basic measurement concepts and terms.

Multilingual Learners Encourage multilingual learners to teach the rest of the class the words for measurement terms, such as tall, short, heavy, and light, in their home language. Children probably know these terms in their home language. In Spanish, for example, the words for height are alto(a) when describing a tall person and bajo(a) when describing a short person, whereas corto(a) is used to describe a short length of something, such as a piece of string.

Social-Emotional Development Young children are born with the desire to connect with those around them. Class read-alouds and activities allow plenty of opportunities for children to observe ways in which people work together to achieve a common goal, solve a problem, or simply help one another.

Social-Emotional Development Good social-emotional skills are vital for children to be able to develop important school-readiiness skills such as cooperation, following directions, demonstrating self-control, and working well with others. As you introduce a topic, have children share together their own knowledge of the topic they are about to explore together.

Mind Builder Learning about cause and effect begins at a very early age and plays a role in all content areas. Throughout today's instruction, make sure children understand the connections between what they or others do and how something moves. Encourage children to keep making these connections throughout the week (Morin/Verywellfamily.com, June 11, 2019).

Multilingual Learners Establishing background knowledge for multilingual learners is a critical component of their comprehension. U.S. games, holidays, foods, nursery rhymes, and even TV shows and movies may be unfamiliar to some multilingual learners. Check children's understanding of concepts before reading aloud to the group.

Gross Motor Skills Children develop gross motor skills, followed by stability (turning, twisting, balancing) and manipulative (throwing, catching, kicking) motor skills. Gross motor skills require thought and deliberate movement. This includes giving and receiving force from objects.

Gross Motor Skills Young children learn about their world by moving their bodies through it. The more children move, the more they feel comfortable and the more they can understand complex concepts. Look for opportunities for children to move on their own and with others to demonstrate how objects move and interact.

Graphic Features Illustrations in picture books engage young children and provide them with meaning of an informational text. Help children enjoy a text and develop their understanding by encouraging them to look closely at illustrations.

Mind Builder Focusing one's attention is a basic executive function skill that children need to develop in order to begin learning. Children must work through several steps to successfully pay attention: 1) be alert, 2) select what to pay attention to and sustain that attention even with outside distractions, and 3) if distracted, shift focus back to task (Rosen, 2019).
Pretend Play Pretend play helps young children develop empathy and build self-esteem. Engaging in pretend play with other children helps them learn how to take turns.

Multilingual Learners Giving children sufficient time to respond after you ask a question is always important, but it is especially important for multilingual learners. It takes time for them to process the question, retrieve the words they know, and formulate and express a response. When you pose a question to a multilingual learner, allow them the time they need to respond.

Multilingual Learners Did you know that the onomatopoeia used to describe animal sounds varies across languages? A pig, for example, goes "oink oink" in English, "boo boo" in Japanese, and "chrum chrum" in Polish! If you have multilingual learners in your classroom, invite them to share the sound their favorite animal makes in their home language.

Vocabulary Development According to researchers, reading picture books to children will help them build a richer vocabulary and understand the rules of grammar, which will in turn help them as they learn to read on their own.

Mind Builder Children's understanding of what they can do is an important part of their emotional development, because it indicates that they have a growing self-awareness. When children begin to feel and express pride about what they can do, it helps them to feel more positive about themselves (Morgan, 2015).

HEADER: Asking and Answering Questions About a Story
TEXT: Asking and Answering Questions About a Story When children listen to a teacher read a story aloud, they have the opportunity to answer and ask questions about the book, which helps them become engaged in reading and making meaning. Discussing stories will also help children's cognitive development.
Dramatic Play Playing can help children make a connection between a topic and what they are physically doing in the classroom. Play can also help children build reading and writing skills.
Multilingual Learners Invite multilingual learners to listen to the reading and retelling of the book. Then, encourage them to speak to others who have the same first language.

Mind Builder Showing curiosity is a key motivation and creativity skill. Four-year-olds naturally want to know why, and encouraging their curiosity is a great way to support their language and intellectual development. Answer their why questions as often as possible (Ames, 1994).

Multilingual Learners Story time provides an opportunity to build English learners' vocabulary. Introducing two new words each day, organized around a theme, is equally effective for both English learners and native speakers. Help children make these words part of their vocabulary by encouraging them to use and reuse these words throughout the week.

Listening Children learn the sounds and intonations of language by listening to you read aloud from various texts—from informational texts to stories to poetry. Children can show off their new skills when they substitute new words in an old song (like "The Farmer in the Dell"), or when they anticipate the end of a line based on a rhyme pattern.

Mind Builder Focusing attention is a key executive function skill. Children might need help paying attention at the end of a long week. To help children attend to your directions, eliminate distractions by making sure toys have been put away in the story-time space and by limiting background noise. Then offer encouragement and praise children's efforts.

Conversation The interactions that happen during back-and-forth communication help shape young children's brains and their social development. The circuits that connect parts of the brain develop at this time. Responsive caregiving and teaching help build an environment for learning, trust, and more!

Vocabulary Development As children's language skills and knowledge develop, having regular interactions with adults who support them helps. These adults can encourage growth by communicating with children about what they are interested in. Conversations should give children the opportunity to hear and use more sophisticated language.

Mind Builder Following routines helps children feel comfortable and secure in the classroom so they can learn. When children follow rules that are part of routines (e.g., washing hands at bathroom time), they are developing important habits that they will take out of the classroom (Vanderbilt University, 2007).

Expansions When children speak in class, expand on what they say. Connect with children by rephrasing their words while adding some new vocabulary. You can also help build on their statements by summarizing what they said or by connecting to their background knowledge. Invite children to continue the conversation.

Music and Movement Singing and moving to songs like "Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes" is more than just fun for children. It helps children develop coordination as they follow the actions in time to the music. They also develop language and memory skills as they repeat the lyrics. Children also become more aware of rhythm, rhyme, and melody as they enjoy the song.

Multilingual Learners Students who speak languages other than English can build their English skills during Story Time. Help by reading with expression and having children use their bodies to act things out. Point out pictures and ask questions about the illustrations and the text. Repeating key information will help children remember new words.

Language Children's oral language, including sentence structure, will grow more sophisticated with opportunities for extended discussion. The weekly theme gives children just that—many occasions to talk about a high-interest topic. To encourage more complex sentences, ask children open-ended questions and expand on their answers.

Mind Builder Discussing the reasons for rules and routines is a great way to teach children important lessons about responsibility and community. Far from turning children into little robots, rules and routines, applied consistently and fairly, help children feel comfortable and gain confidence (Vanderbilt, 2007)!

Technology Point out the technology in the world around us: tablets, phones, bicycles, motor vehicles, vacuum cleaners, televisions, trucks, checkout registers, and on and on. Point out that some technology, such as tablets or phones children may have used, requires careful fingering and attention. Remind children that technology only works if the person uses it in the right way.

Multilingual Learners Children learn by example. Model the process of learning a different language by learning a few words and phrases of your students' first languages. Learn to say "hello" and "good job," as well as the names of foods. Post multilingual picture cards of various foods around the room. Little learners will be impressed by your efforts!

Cultural Sensitivity Keep in mind that cultures differ in how they conceptualize and deal with everyday experiences such as what to wear, what and when to eat, and how to treat illnesses. As you read aloud, be mindful of the fact that the behaviors described in a story may not conform to what goes on in some children's families. Encourage children to share and compare their own experiences.

Mind Builder Preschoolers learn problem-solving skills from frequent experience solving problems that arise in their day-to-day lives. Allow them to find their own solutions to their problems whenever possible. Help them by asking open-ended questions (e.g., "What could you do to solve that problem?"), but do not solve their problems for them (Miller and Poole, 2019).

Multilingual Learners All language learners need repeated exposures to words to gain a deeper understanding of what they mean and how they are used. Presenting vocabulary in context is an especially effective way for children to gain these exposures, because they learn to form associations between words.

Healthy Habits Young children have a tremendous ability to develop habits that will benefit them for life. Focusing on how to practice self-care—not only when they are sick but also when they are well—can help them establish good health habits that will stay with them always.

Vocabulary Development Preschoolers learn new words through conversations with adults, but also through songs, stories, and word games. Provide a variety of ways for children to experience new words through multiple experiences.

Multilingual Learners When words in different languages share similar spelling and meaning, they are called cognates. Spanish and English share many cognates; pointing them out can help English learners in the classroom. The English word dinosaur has the Spanish cognate dinosaurio. Both mean "terrible lizard" and come from modern Latin.

Mind Builder Showing empathy is a skill that can be developed like many others. Children need to be able to identify others' emotions and then imagine feeling that way themselves. They should also think about what they can do to help, and what they would want and need if they felt the same way. Discussing pictures and stories can help them develop these skills (Dewar, 2017).

Categorizing Young children naturally begin to notice what is the same and what is different in their world. Encouraging this kind of categorizing is an important part of early education, helping children define and organize their world. Support children as they notice similarities and differences based on factors such as color and the shapes of objects.

Rhymes and Chants Teaching children common rhyming chants and songs is fun for children, and it is also helps them develop an awareness of rhythm, rhyme, and the sounds of syllables and words. This awareness serves as a foundation for associating sounds with letters as children learn to read.

Multilingual Learners As children begin to write, invite them to write in the language they use at home. Then share these works on bulletin boards to encourage children's expression. It will also be helpful to children, if possible, to pair them with other students who speak their home language.

Verbs Help children with a different home language or culture build language skills by providing a simple sentence frame to use. For example, while pointing to the rooster, say,"The rooster _____ today." Scaffold children's responses by having them show what the rooster did, say one word, or repeat the sentence frame.

Mind Builder Emotional development is an essential aspect of growing up. Provide opportunities for children to explore self-awareness and demonstrate how to express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills. For example, have children discuss how they used to react to a situation but how they would now act in a different, more effective way (Miller, 2019).

Scaffolding Ask children questions that help them progress just a bit beyond what they can currently do. By carefully challenging children to go a little further in their learning, you allow them to feel a sense of growth and accomplishment without being overwhelmed. Differentiate your questions as needed to help children continue to grow and learn.

Fluent Thinking Fluent thinking is one aspect of problem solving. Fluent thinkers are ones who can take information and see many possibilities or view objects or situations in new ways. Give children opportunities to develop fluent thinking by allowing them to brainstorm multiple answers to a single question. Remind them to turn to an adult when necessary.

Multilingual Learners Music entertains and energizes! Music also builds language skills for children who are learning multiple languages. Through music, children can gain a better grasp of sentence structure and grammar—for example, past tense. Use a familiar tune to help children learn the regular past tense and lodge it in their memories.

Vocabulary Development While research tells us that reading aloud grows vocabulary, it also confirms that reading in an animated way encourages children to interact more with a text. To get children involved, practice before you read, give children a focus, and ask guided, open-ended questions like "Why did we growl loudly as we read along?"

Mind Builder We develop emotionally as we grow in experiences. Even before children begin walking and talking, they feel a clear sense of pride when they accomplish something new. As you discuss accomplishments, emphasize that it's more about trying your best than being the best. (Massey, 2018)

Conversational Language Children learn authentically when it comes to conversational language, but you can still explicitly teach it. That's why it's so important to set up the classroom for guided-play opportunities. As children focus and create, foster intentional conversational know-how by asking and answering questions.

Singing, Dancing, and Performing Guided playtime is a great opportunity to discuss sequencing. After children sing, dance, or perform, have them review the order in which they sang the song or performed the dance. Use open-ended questions to find out why. This strengthens memorization skills and creates "muscle memory" for sequencing in other areas.

Multilingual Learners Not only does music entertain and energize, it also builds language skills for children who are learning multiple languages. Through music, children can gain a better grasp of sentence structure and grammar. Try using familiar tunes so that a child can engage his or her first language as a scaffold.

Sustaining Attention Attention problems affect as many as 40% of preK children. As you read aloud, minimize distractions by reducing background noise and having children focus on your face as well as on the pages of the book you are reading. Develop consistent routines that grab children's attention and help them to focus on the task at hand.

Mind Builder Children at this age are just beginning to be able to recognize pride in themselves. You can stimulate this emotion by pointing it out: "You did a great job! You must feel very happy and proud of yourself." It is equally important to model pride—for example, by saying, "I am proud of the job we did cleaning up today!" (Terebush, 2017).

Speaking Clearly By age 4, children should be able to speak in understandable sentences. For children who lack articulation or who mumble, try repeating clearly and crisply what they say, so that they hear how their words should sound. If children continue to respond in one- or two-word phrases, encourage them to add on, and model how to do so.

Multilingual Learners As children try to compose sentences to respond to questions about the reading, some bilingual children may mix words from their two languages. This kind of code mixing is natural and not problematic. To guide children, you may wish to provide sentence frames such as: "_____ drew these pictures" and "This horse is made of _____."

Performance Anxiety Children with perfectionist tendencies may rip up papers, become weepy, and criticize others. Learning to set realistic standards is a difficult lesson for young children. Try to make your classroom a calm and safe place where failure is an expected part of growth and learning is process-oriented rather than outcome-oriented.

Scientific Thinking When children use building blocks, they are exploring the scientific principles of height, balance, and gravity. Asking them questions about what they're doing and what they observe reinforces these principles. Center activities stimulate different kinds of thinking and are important to children's developing capacities to apply ideas to materials.

Mind Builder In the preK classroom, persisting in attempting to solve problems can happen anytime and anywhere. Explicit and direct role playing serves as skill building before problems occur. One of the best ways to teach emotional and executive function skills is by role-playing, which provides an authentic scenario in a safe space (Thomas and Thorne, 2009).

Cross-Text Connections As children read and listen, they naturally make connections between new stories and those they have previously read. Help children make connections with open-ended requests like, "Tell me more about that," or "Give me more details." Then restate: "You're thinking about a few different stories with a Big Bad Wolf character."

Social Development Build a community of learners by allowing children to work among themselves when it comes to activities like building a tower. When children are engaging with each other on a team, they are not only learning from other children but can in turn teach other children.
Building Background Children's knowledge of the world makes a big impact on their read-aloud comprehension. Spend time before reading to introduce important concepts to children.

Mind Builder Developing self-esteem can be hard for some children. Guide them into seeing the good in their accomplishments by giving specific praise and asking questions that help them see what they succeeded in. Sometimes a simple "You should be proud" is enough prodding to help build their self-esteem (Emmons, n.d.).

Multilingual Learners Sharing birthday songs in different languages teaches all students the richness of world languages and the universality of birthday traditions. If children are shy about sharing birthday songs in their home languages, try enlisting the aid of parents or community members. You could even look for and play clips posted online.

Language Preschoolers begin to string together longer sentences with more detail. For example, a four-year-old might combine two related sentences into one—"Bear paddled his boat and hiked through the woods." Encourage children to express the bigger ideas developing in their minds by providing frames, such as, "First Bear_____, then Bear _____."

Mind Builder Making connections is a key skill for preschool children to develop. Teachers can support children by providing them with opportunities to make observations and then letting them draw or make charts about what they observed. Teachers can also ask children questions about what they observed (Resourcesforearlylearning.org/Educators/Connections).

Categorizing Preschool children are able to recognize patterns. The ability to sort and categorize will help them with literacy tasks (e.g., sorting words with the same sounds) and in other domains. Providing children with the opportunities to sort items or to tell what is the same and different will help them develop these skills.

Cross-Text Connections Children enhance their learning when they can make connections between texts. Help them notice if, for example, the same author has written two or more books. Discuss whether books share a genre or whether they have a similar topic. By making these connections, children become more engaged with reading and develop their memory skills.

Multilingual Learners Recognizing cognates can help Spanish speakers learn English more quickly. As you discuss different activities for different seasons, point out that the word activity has the Spanish cognate actividad.

Mind Builder By this time of the year, class rules are well established. Ask children to share the rules for talking and sharing in circle time and story time as well as in small groups. Encourage children to state the rules in a positive way. e.g., "Raise your hand" or "Take turns," rather than "Don't interrupt" (Monopoli/Uh.edu, Adventures in Inquiry).

Read-Aloud Comprehension Making inferences is a key read-aloud comprehension skill, but four- and five-year-olds will require help to express ideas not stated in the text. Show children how you make an inference through Think Alouds. For example, ask how the stem helps a plant. Then explain what makes you think it carries water from the roots and helps the plant stay upright, so it can get light from the sun.

Multilingual Learners Relational words include words that show location (that is, prepositions) and words that compare things (-er, -est words). These words can challenge English learners. When singing the circle time song, point to a plant diagram to illustrate each relational word (in, from, on) as you sing it. To teach comparisons, use whole phrases (is bigger than).

Print Concepts Preschoolers are just learning that we read print from left to right. Show this by sweeping your finger across text as you read some pages, and explain what you are doing. Many informational texts include special features such as Fun Fact boxes. Show that these items, too, are read from left to right.

Curiosity Children are innately curious about their world. Teaching science in the preschool classroom can help further that curiosity. One practice you can implement to encourage your students' interest in science is to bring in objects from outside (for example, rocks and sticks) that the children can touch, smell, and otherwise examine.

Mind Builder Persisting in a task comes naturally to preschoolers, but when the task becomes too challenging, they can get frustrated. When this happens, you can offer a bit of guidance. For example, if a child is having a hard time with a puzzle, you could calmly suggest, "Would it help if you turned that piece around?" (Young, Reed/NAEYC.org, Oct/Nov 2017).

Multilingual Learners Preschoolers are not too young to learn to use cognates. When bilingual or multilingual children have cognate awareness, they will be able to use cognates in their first language to help them understand a second language. You can foster development of this awareness by pointing out cognates when you are reading aloud to students.

Cross-Text Connections Children can gain valuable reading comprehension skills when they can make connections between texts. When you read aloud to your students, you can encourage these connections by asking the children questions such as, "Does this story remind you of another story we've read?" and "How is this story different from other stories we've read?"

Gross Motor Skills Gross motor skills are important for children to develop in order to function independently in daily life, play with their peers, and develop fine motor skills. You can nurture the growth of gross motor skills in your students by incorporating simple games, such as hopscotch and Simon Says, into indoor or outdoor playtime.

Mind Builder Encourage children to talk and share by asking questions that relate to the child's experiences or interests. Add to what the child says and model new language. Make sure to give children enough time to respond to questions and to share their own experiences (National Center for Quality Teaching and Learning, 2012).

Multilingual Learners Some animals, such as deer, may be familiar to children, even if they don't know the English word. Other animals, such as porcupines or chipmunks, may be unfamiliar. Discuss each animal with children, noting the animal's unique characteristics. Extend children's vocabulary by discussing other animals children might find in the woods.

Multilingual Learners Learning both English and Spanish words for vegetables might help children recognize words that are used at home. We say peas in English and chícharos or guisantesin Spanish. We say corn in English and maíz in Spanish. We say carrots in English, and zanahorias in Spanish. Reviewing both can help emphasize the unique knowledge multilingual learners can bring.

Connect to Science Encourage children to observe the natural world. Look closely at different shapes, sizes, and colors of leaves. Go outside with children. Encourage them to call out the animals they see. You can help them use a magnifying glass to observe nonpoisonous insects they encounter outside.

Sentence Structure Improve sentence structure through conversation. When a child says something grammatically incorrect, model the correct way. Incorporate activities requiring children to repeat phrases and sentences that use correct grammar. Focus on one grammatical component to avoid overloading children with too many new concepts.

Mind Builder Help children label and understand their own feelings and develop strategies for coping. You can say, "It looks like you are feeling upset about something. Let's take a deep breath together to calm down." It is important for adults to support children's effort to self-regulate and talk about their feelings (Kids Help Line, 2018).

Multilingual Learners Review multiple meanings of words that come up in reading and conversation. For example, children may be familiar with the word train to identify a vehicle that runs on tracks, but not as a verb meaning to teach. They may know tip as the end of one's nose but not tip meaning to lean or topple. Have children demonstrate each meaning with you while saying the word, touching the tip of their nose and miming a tipping object. Prior to reading aloud, check children's understanding of words that may be confusing.

Oral Language This story has many irregular past-tense verbs, including rode, got, thought, began, came, and seen. You can help children with irregular past-tense verbs by immersing them in language from read-aloud books and by modeling sophisticated language. Repetition of sentences from books will help children internalize sentence structures.

Language Milestones Celebrate children's linguistic competencies. Most three- to four-year-olds will be able to say their name and age, speak 250 to 500 words, answer simple questions, speak in sentences of five to six words, speak in complete sentences (by age four), speak clearly (although they may not be fully comprehensible until age four), and tell stories.

Mind Builder To encourage and support persistence in problem solving, provide activities such as puzzles and math games with more than one way to a solution. Resist the urge to fix problems for children, and encourage children to keep trying. Remind them that learning is a part of growing, and that we all must persist in order to learn (Reed and Young, 2017).

Cognitive Milestones Celebrate children's cognitive accomplishments. Most three- to four-year-olds will be able to name familiar colors, understand same and different, compare sizes, count, sort objects by shape and color, complete age-appropriate puzzles, identify common objects and pictures, follow three-part commands, remember parts of a story, and understand times of day such as morning and night.

Movement Milestones Celebrate children's physical competencies. Most three- to four-year-olds will be able to walk up and down stairs; kick, throw, and catch a ball; climb; run; ride a tricycle; hop and stand on one foot for up to five seconds; walk forward and backward; bend over without falling; and help put on and remove clothing.

Multilingual Learners Ask volunteers to help teach the class to count to ten in their home language. If possible, write the words on chart paper or a word wall where children can see them. If the language uses a different alphabet, ask an adult in the community to write the words for you. Show children that everyone–including you–can keep learning new things.

Pretend Play Research has shown that pretend play is a vital component of social and cognitive growth in the preK years. Pretend play helps to expand children's vocabulary, language, and creativity. Role-playing also improves social skills, including communication, problem solving, empathy, and the ability to share another's perspective.

Mind Builder You can help children learn to persist by providing lots of activities that involve solving problems with more than one solution. Support children's independence, and resist the urge to fix a problem so that children see that they can solve the problem independently. Provide gentle guidance if frustration sets in (Reed and Young, 2017).

HEADER: Verbal and Nonverbal Group Discussion Rules
TEXT: Verbal and Nonverbal Group Discussion Rules Model classroom etiquette and discuss the concept of interrupting. Help children use the phrase excuse me as they act out scenarios when they would like to say something but someone else is speaking. Discuss nonverbal ways of communicating that you want a turn to speak and how to wait politely and not interrupt.

Cross-Text Connections Help children understand that fictional characters often have ideas that apply to real life. The dreams of a story character to become a champion could easily be the dreams of a real-life child. Studies have shown that pretend play can be beneficial for lifelong learning and later success.

Multilingual Learners For multilingual learners, listening is an important part of gaining knowledge of a language. Invite children whose first language isn't English to listen to the reading and retelling of the book. Then encourage them to speak to others who have the same first language in order to express their ideas comfortably.

Classroom Environment Creating a welcoming environment can help children transition from home to preK. Keep special objects from home in the space designated for each child. Specific examples may include a favorite teddy bear or a drawing the child did. These will help make the space more like home for the child.

Mind Builder Remember that children may not have the words to say what they're feeling. Point out an emotion a child is showing, such as feeling proud, and ask questions about how and why they're feeling that way. Giving them words to describe the feeling can help them with relationships and their own mental and emotional health.

Social Studies As children develop and experience more social interactions, they begin to notice differences between people—in gender, race, traditions, language, and culture. Research shows that teaching children to respect and appreciate differences early on in their development is key to preventing future bias and intolerance.

Multilingual Learners For many learners, especially for multilingual learners, comprehension can be one of the most challenging reading skills to grasp. In "Reading Comprehension Strategies for English Language Learners," the author suggests that teachers (1) build background knowledge, (2) teach vocabulary explicitly, and (3) check comprehension frequently.

Mind Builder Healthy social-emotional development helps children forge new friendships with peers and adults. To foster social-emotional growth, consider using emotion words and encouraging children to do the same, especially when working through conflicts.

Asking for Help Your classroom should be a place where children feel safe and comfortable asking for help. Children need to know how to ask for help—not every time a task is hard, but definitely before they feel frustrated to continue. Model requests: "I want to do this, but I need help, please" or "Can you explain this, please?" (Kennedy-Moore, 2018)

Mind Builder Children at this age are just learning to apply language to their feelings. If they are unable to articulate how they feel, it may result in a classroom meltdown. You can help them develop emotional vocabulary by noticing and naming their feelings and by encouraging them to express their emotions in words (Joseph and Strain, 2013).

Positive Body Language Reading body language is an important skill. Children need to understand that people use their bodies to convey emotions. Model positive body language—stand up tall, make eye contact, and avoid folding your arms. "Read" children's body language aloud: "I can tell that you are excited; you're waving your hand" (Ruland, 2018).

Facial Expression Recognition Most very young children can easily discern expressions of fear and happiness in others. Other emotions may be harder to recognize, but as children mature, they become better able to distinguish between expressions. Impairment in facial expression recognition is often a marker for autism spectrum disorder (Rodger et al., 2015; Loth et al., 2018).

Multilingual Learners Make sure that children understand the difference between feeling better physically and feeling better mentally. In English, we say that we feel well when we are physically healthy. We say that we feel good when we are happy or content. The word better is the comparative form of both well and good. Even native speakers may get confused!

Print Concepts Reading to children from an early age is one of the best ways to help them develop the pre-literacy skills they need before they can read. As you read aloud a book's title and the names of the creator(s), run your finger below each word. While reading a story, ask children to identify key words depicted in the illustrations.

Mind Builder Research shows that creative play is important in young children's brain development. Though children are not aware of it, play is serious work for them! It provides opportunities to express and cope with emotions and supports cognitive growth as they explore new and unexpected ways of thinking and using materials.

Cross-Text Connections When we point out cross-text connections to young children, we are teaching them to be more engaged readers/listeners. By guiding children to notice connections between texts, we are helping them to realize a deeper understanding of both texts and to recognize that the larger concepts have meaning in many different contexts.

Multilingual Learners It's not unusual for children's expressive language to lag behind their receptive language. They can understand more spoken language than they can use for expressing themselves. Multilingual learners can benefit from story prompts that invite children to act out parts of a story instead of asking for a verbal response.

Healthy Habits Just as we teach children good manners, we must teach them good hygiene habits. Starting young helps build a foundation that will grow with children. Incorporating specific times to wash hands throughout the school day (before snack and lunch, after using the bathroom) will go far in preventing the spread of germs from child to child.

Mind Builder Scientific studies show that teaching kindness benefits growing children emotionally and physically. Feeling kindness themselves helps children develop into caring, happy adults. The benefits of teaching kindness in school include a sense of belonging, increased peer acceptance, and improved self-esteem.

Good Manners Most adults begin teaching their children good manners early in life. Many people simply model appropriate language and behaviors. Manners are important in all interactions, making it essential for getting along with others. Learning good manners early builds good habits and gives children advantages in many areas of life.

Mind Builder Young children are naturally egocentric. They need to be taught conflict-resolution skills. When conflicts arise, adults often step in and resolve the conflict. Instead teach conflict-resolution strategies: Use a calm voice, listen to all sides, encourage children to suggest solutions, and choose one to try out. Discuss differences in outcome based on the solution chosen.

Multilingual Learners When teaching concepts such as manners to children from various cultures, keep in mind that not all social codes are the same across cultures. Take time to learn about the social norms in cultures represented by your multilingual learners.

Using Picture Clues When you read, always stop to engage children in looking for picture clues. In many books, there are photographs or illustrations of objects and settings that are familiar to children from their lives. As you read, invite children to notice visual images of recognizable real-world things within the book. Children will love seeking out the clues.

Mind Builder Children progress from parallel play (playing next to each other), to associative play, and then to creative play. Playing with others is an important Mind Builder skill that leads to increased conversations, growth in vocabulary, and self-regulation (Singer, ed., 2006).

Cross-Text Connections Connecting content from different texts leads children to look more deeply into each one, and possibly glean new understandings. This is helpful when texts of different genres are used, such as narratives and informational texts. Connecting the poster to the book brings a sense of realism to Ming's story, while providing more detailed examples of following rules.

Voting Being part of a group and recognizing that rules are important for the group is valuable to learn in preK. As children progress through the year, help them make group decisions by setting up a process of voting. Voting can be done by showing hands, counting chips or cubes, or making a graph with sticky notes.

Mind Builder Growth mindset is the idea that the more we struggle to learn new things, the more our brain grows. Persistence is an essential skill in school and life. To teach persistence, compliment effort and hard work with comments such as, "I can see you worked hard on this," or "I'm glad you didn't give up!" (Zimmerman, 1981).

Multilingual Learners Words taught in the context of a story allow learners to comprehend vocabulary more easily, as does encouraging children to share their new words at home. To celebrate the diversity in your classroom, allow multilingual children to share translations for each new word in their own languages.

Social-Emotional Development When discussing neighborhoods, encourage discussion of the unique cultural aspects of different communities. Developing respect and appreciation for diversity early on can help prevent children from developing misconceptions about other people. This way, you raise their cognitive development levels and increase their capacity for connection.

Print Concepts Before children learn that groups of letters form words, they can become familiar with print concepts. These basic principles introduce children to the idea that written words have meaning. Children must understand this before they can learn any other literacy skills. As you reread the book, point out to children the page numbers and pictures. Point out that on every page you are reading left to right, from the top of the page to the bottom.

Multilingual Learners Pointing out words that are similar in Spanish and in English is very helpful for Spanish-speaking children as well as for English-speaking children. Cognates are the words in the two languages that share a similar meaning, spelling, and even pronunciation. Identifying cognates is a helpful resource for Spanish-speaking children.

Mind Builder Preschool-age children need to develop persistence rather than give up on a challenging task. Teachers of children in this age group have an important role in developing this skill, which is helpful both now and later in all areas of life. Praising effort, providing challenges, and offering guidance all help children master this ability (Young and Reed, 2017).

Read-Aloud Comprehension Geography helps children understand that the different places and people in the world are connected. Picture clues can help children become aware of the different landforms and of the plants and animals that live in a habitat. Children of this age are just beginning to understand that there is a world beyond their own.

Read-Aloud Comprehension Inference is a skill that extends beyond literacy. Introduce children to the idea of using picture clues to learn things that the author doesn't say with words. Combining picture clues with what they already know will help them make inferences about the story.

Dramatic Play Acting out parts of a story is a great opportunity to help children connect to reading. While they are playing, they begin to connect their actions with the words on the page. The fun game they are playing becomes associated with the words on the page, which makes the children more excited to get another book.

Reading Comprehension Nursery rhymes do more than entertain children—they rhyme and have rhythm. These two elements help children hear syllables and recognize the sounds phonemes make, which ultimately helps them encode, decode, blend, and—read! Emphasize the rhythm or rhyme when you read a story with either or both.

Mind Builder There's no doubt that imaginative play is just as important as—if not more important than—traditional structured outdoor recess. Children who engage in imaginative play develop larger vocabularies earlier and begin to learn social skills such as empathy, problem solving, and acceptable interactions (Ginsburg, 2007).

Scientific Thinking Children may not yet be familiar with what materials come from the earth. Introduce them to some of these materials, such as sand, metals, clay, and stone. Invite children to help you make a list of things that come from the earth.

Physical Activity Preschool-age children enjoy movement and will actually focus better, learn more, and retain information longer if they are able to move while learning. In most classrooms, sitting is the norm. Engaging children to move as you sing songs provides the boost children need for extra mental and physical stimulation.

Learning the Alphabet Learning the letters of the alphabet is a prerequisite to eventually learning to read and write. The rate at which children learn their ABCs varies, but exposure to print is key. To encourage letter recognition, point out and name letters in the room around you and label children's desks and cubbies with their names.

Multilingual Learners One effective strategy in supporting multilingual learners is family engagement. Meet with parents to discuss children's exposure to both their home language and English. Determine ways to include cultural influences into activities. If possible, include both English and children's home language on classroom labels and displays.

Brain Development Children naturally explore their world through "sensory play." Providing opportunities for children to actively engage their senses helps build nerve connections in the brain. These connections are crucial in strengthening children's abilities to process and respond to sensory stimulation. Point out that our skin is used for touching, and that touch is one of our five senses, along with hearing, sight, taste, and smell.

Gross Motor Skills Gross motor skills are important to children's physical development. Activities that require large muscle movement, such as scarf dancing, help build these skills in children. Gross motor abilities impact children's success in school and in participating in everyday functions, such as sitting upright, writing and drawing, and playing sports.

Vocabulary Development Children's vocabulary is influenced not only by the quantity of words they hear but by the quality of words. By three to four years of age, children are ready to be exposed to more challenging words. For example, saying humongous instead of big or peek instead of look can positively contribute to children's vocabulary development.

Mind Builder Novelty sparks curiosity in the young child. To encourage curiosity, model being curious, ask questions, answer children's questions, be spontaneous, and encourage observation (Miller/Scholastic.com).

Multilingual Learners Doing multiple readings of the same book over the course of several days is especially beneficial to multilingual preschoolers. At this age, children are working to make sense of their native language on top of a new language. Repetition is crucial.

Cause and Effect Without knowing it, children are continually identifying the connection between one event and another—even simply when learning about weather. For example, you may demonstrate cause-and-effect awareness by saying, "Because it's raining today, I brought an umbrella." Look for daily opportunities to help children identify cause-and-effect relationships.

Drama Children are natural storytellers. Reenacting what they've read helps to build developing literacy skills. Even with a nonfiction selection, acting out a familiar experience or demonstrating activities related to a book's subject helps children make personal connections to the information. And it's fun!

Letter-Sound Correspondences Teaching children letter names is great, but teaching the sounds that letters represent is the first step in growing children's pre-reading skills. During Circle Time activities, the teacher provides a word orally. This directs the child's attention to the sound first. Only after the sound is identified is the connection to the letter made.

Mind Builder Before children have the vocabulary to express their feelings, they do so through facial expressions, body language, and behaviors. Children need to be taught to put names to feelings before they can learn to self-regulate their reactions. Acknowledge the feelings first, and then model appropriate responses to them as opportunities arise (Martinelli, n.d.).

Size Young children are engaged in measurement activities without even realizing it. "Fairness" is very important to preschoolers, so they're acutely aware if someone else "got more" or "has a bigger piece." When you overhear such conversations, build upon children's understanding by asking, "How do you know? How can we measure that?"

Multilingual Learners Research suggests that reading stories in one language at a time is the best approach in a multilingual classroom, even if two languages appear on a page. However, research has also shown that explaining what a story will be about, in both languages (if possible), prior to reading is a beneficial practice for all children as well.

Writing Development At this age, children are moving from scribbles to marks that stand for something specific. When asked, children will explain that they've written a grocery list, a to-do list, or some other specific type of writing. Provide daily writing opportunities, such as setting up a sign-in and sign-out routine where children practice writing their names.

Science Teaching science to young children instills a love of science and encourages critical thinking. Tapping into and encouraging young children's natural curiosity about the world will help prepare them for a future in which many jobs will require science, technology, engineering, and mathematics skills.

Mind Builder Curious children ask "why" questions to help make sense of the world around them. Educators aim to encourage "why" questions to represent deeper cognitive thinking. One method is to model asking "why" during read-alouds. When appropriate, turn questions around to children by asking, "Why do YOU think... ?".

Folktales Folktales are powerful tools through which children can learn about different cultures and traditions. Because their simple plotlines are easy to follow, remember, and retell, folktales help develop children's reading fluency, vocabulary, and comprehension skills. They also model two important development skills—decision making and conflict resolution.

Repeated Read-Alouds Research has shown that reading aloud alone isn't what's most important; it's the way a story is read aloud multiple times. The first read-aloud is for enjoyment; the second, to build on children's comprehension; and the third, to guide children in retelling the story.

Inquiry Skills Encouraging children to ask questions nurtures children's natural curiosity. When children ask questions after learning new ideas, show an active interest in their questions. Providing children with simple explanations can lead to more questions, which can lead to rich discussions.
