Mind Builder Toys and other manipulatives help children make connections to the real world. Children can identify and solve problems like figuring out how to balance blocks or building a tower without falling. Children can practice their problem-solving skills in a tactile and concrete way.

Biology When children explore the world around them, they begin to develop their observational skills. When children ask "why" animals behave in certain ways, they are building curiosity and strengthening their learning. Teaching children about animals is an opportunity to let them become cognizant learners and beginner behaviorists.

Empathy Children love to read about animals, especially baby animals. Teaching children about the responsibilities of parenthood and how babies learn and grow helps children understand that they too have a lot to learn. Showing children how difficult it is to keep a baby safe and fed helps to foster empathy for children's own caregivers.

Vocabulary Development It is important to encourage children's vocabulary development so that they develop the language and literacy skills necessary to succeed in school. The adults in a child's life play a significant role in helping a child learn new words.

Mind Builders Children with emotional competence are likely to do well in school and engage in positive relationships with other children and family. Take time to develop this competency by setting aside time for reflection throughout the day and encouraging children to share how they're feeling and why they may be feeling a certain way (MDRC.org/Social and Emotional Competence).

Feeling Frustrated Frustration is a big part of learning. When children become overwhelmed with frustration, give them a minute to cool off, and then ask questions that will help them discover a solution on their own. Helping them create their own solution instead of giving one to them will help boost their self-confidence.

Taking Care of Pets Children this age can learn how to handle their pets carefully. They can also drop a treat onto the floor for their cat or dog to eat. Children might be too young to feed or walk a pet, but they can assist with these duties.

Science Concepts There are seven basic science process concepts, or process skills, that young children should learn in preschool: observing, comparing, classifying, measuring, communicating, inferring, and predicting.

Alphabet Knowledge Research shows that children learn the letters of the alphabet best when instruction focuses on five things: letter name, letter sound, phonological awareness, letter in printed text, and letter formation.

Mind Builder Working memory is an important executive function skill that powers much of our learning and behavior. Working memory helps us remember and use information for short periods of time. It helps children follow directions to complete a task, remember story details while a book is being read aloud, remember numbers while counting, and much more! (Understood.org/8 Working Memory Boosters)

Open-Ended Questions Open-ended questions are questions that can't be answered with yes or no, and that do not have a right or wrong answer. Open-ended questions encourage conversation and higher-order thinking. They also help create a positive classroom environment!

Text-to-Text Connections Showing children how ideas in one text are similar to ideas in another helps them improve comprehension. They can begin to make meaning of facts and start to understand that learning is interconnected. The facts they learn about animals, for example, are not random. All animals have unique features and characteristics that help them survive. Children can begin to make comparisons based on facts found in different texts.

Multilingual Learners Children benefit when objects are labeled in both English and their home language. When introducing target vocabulary, learn the translations of the words, and display multilingually labeled illustrations or photographs when possible.
Multilingual Learners Children's early experiences with language form the foundation for later language learning. This is true whether they hear and/or speak one language or many languages.

Mind Builder Research shows that helping children develop personal boundaries builds empathy. Helping children understand the rules of respecting other people's personal space enables them to develop their own boundaries (Argyle, 2013).

Cultures Reading and talking about what makes each person "one of a kind" helps children learn to make observations on their own. Children begin to understand that each of us has features, customs, and characteristics that make us special. Understanding this means children are becoming more aware of themselves and others.

Sensory Support Add a two-minute sensory experience to your morning a few times a week. Play different types of music, breathe in new smells, touch objects from nature, or view a cultural artifact or something from nature. Children's sensory knowledge will add up over time.

Cultural Diversity Children love to read about children from other places. Teaching children about what makes other cultures special (traditions, food, music), as well as identifying similarities among them, can help them develop cultural awareness.

Fruits and Vegetables Having early positive associations to healthy foods makes it easier for children to try fruits and vegetables. Playing games, singing songs, and reading books about different fruits and vegetables will help encourage children to try foods rich in nutrients.

Mind Builder Henry Ford once said, "If you think you can, you can. If you think you can't, you can't. Either way, you are right." Create a nurturing environment that encourages positive thinking (Epstein, 2007).

Writing Development Emergent writing is a child's first attempt at writing. Children as young as two years old can imitate writing by drawing and making markings that represent thoughts. This is the beginning of the stages children progress through as they learn to write. This is an important predictor of children's reading and writing skills.

Multilingual Learners "Code-mixing"—combining different languages in a single sentence—is not a sign of developmental delay. Children who are multilingual are often learning two languages at once. They might only know certain words in one language. Encourage children by pointing out that words can be like different fruits mixed together in a salad.

Vocabulary Development Introduce children to new words by using them yourself. Do this by being a walking thesaurus, using synonyms frequently. Often a synonym is more descriptive than the original word. Use sensory words to describe the foods children like to eat: juicy, sweet, crisp, salty, spicy, soft, crunchy, and so on.

Active Listening Young children can be taught that active listening involves more than just their ears. It also requires their eyes and their feelings. Encourage children to listen actively to read-aloud books and ask each other questions about characters and events. How can children connect story characters and events to their own experiences?

Mind Builder Preschoolers may not have developed much impulse control. When they feel something, they are likely to act on it. This may include snatching a toy away from another child if they want to play with it or getting upset when told they need to wait. Encourage children to respect one another's boundaries and to be patient (Kochanska, 2000).

Healthy Habits Repetition and encouragement are the keys to teaching children about personal hygiene. Whether it's washing their hands or blowing their nose, be sure to remind children to take care of themselves. After they have done the correct action, give children praise.

Multilingual Learners Practice, whether alone or with others, is important for multilingual learners. Make sure to provide regular opportunities for children to practice and develop both language and understanding of content. Practice should have specific learning goals with feedback that helps learning.

Turn and Talk When Turn and Talk is used, all children have a chance to share their thinking. Verbalizing thinking scaffolds their understanding and provides talk at a peer level. As an oral language strategy, it provides children with a scaffolded time to share thinking and formulate thoughts.

Sound Awareness It is important to guide children to understand that sounds are represented by letters of the alphabet and that the letters represent sounds. This helps children learn to read words and break words into their sound parts.

Mind Builder Children in preschool are learning how to play and interact with their peers. It is a time when they begin to understand how their behavior, positive or negative, affects others. It's an important time to teach children about sharing and taking turns on the playground (Anthony, n.d.).

Making Connections When children have a purpose for reading, they can better understand the text. By showing children how the characters in a story are similar to people they encounter every day, they can assimilate the lesson from the story.

Nursery Rhymes Counting nursery rhymes like "Five Little Froggies Jumping On the Bed" are fun and important learning tools for young children. The rhythm and rhymes help children develop the ability to hear syllables and recognize the sounds phonemes make. Those skills lead them to being able to understand sound and letter relationships and blend sounds!

Multilingual Learners Children need a variety of experiences and opportunities to learn language. Pair multilingual children with speakers who have strong English-language skills. Pair children during outdoor playtime, and encourage partners to talk by providing simple phrases, such as, "Do you want to _______?" (swing, slide, throw the ball, play tag)

Alphabet Knowledge Many languages, such as English, Spanish, and French, are alphabet languages. To be able to read, children must understand that the system of letters stands for a series of sounds. Children who can recognize letters with accuracy will find it easier to understand the sounds linked to the letters.

Mind Builder Often we need to help children understand that a goal can be reached "one step at a time." Look for opportunities for children to set a goal that they can reach in a short amount of time, such as completing a picture for a class display. Note the steps that they followed and talk about how they felt when they reached the goal (Parents.com/Goal Setting).

Nutrition Suggest to family members that when children are afraid to try new foods, having adults eat the "new" food with them is very helpful. Encourage them to talk about the flavor and texture of the foods they share.

Multilingual Learners Multilingual learners will benefit from stories that use repeating language. Take this opportunity to have children say the repeating parts of the story with you to help them gain confidence using language. Make sure they understand the meaning of each sentence.

Making Connections When children make personal connections to characters in a story, they understand the main ideas and themes more deeply. Help children explain personal experiences that help them make connections to the characters and events in the story.

Mind Builder Setting a goal and taking small steps to achieve it is a key executive function skill. When something new seems too big or overwhelming to learn, it can be broken down into smaller, more achievable steps that help us to reach goals and acquire new skills (Cunningham et al., 2000).

Gross Motor Skills Large locomotor movements strengthen children's muscle tone and prepare them for more distinct, finer movements such as writing and using scissors. Dancing, jumping, and clapping to music will help children develop gross motor skills and feel confident as they move in the world!

Move to Learn Preschool children are always on the move! Incorporating movement and play into their day not only makes learning fun, but also helps to reinforce connections in children's brains that help them to learn and retain new skills.

Alphabet Assessment Continue to assess children's recognition of uppercase and lowercase letters in and out of sequence. Speed and accuracy in recognizing letters will lay a foundation for pre-reading and reading. Assessments will help you plan instruction based on each child's needs.

Mind Builder Setting goals helps children take responsibility for their learning. Setting goals will guide children to develop grit. Encourage children to break the goal down into smaller steps (Meltzer, L., 2010).

Making Predictions Making predictions is an important skill because it helps children become active thinkers. They can make predictions based on prior knowledge or what they have already read or heard. These types of connections help young readers stay interested in a story and make a story more meaningful.

Creative Expression When children have opportunities to develop creative expression, the trait will feel more natural. Music, art, dance, and drama all contribute to fine motor skills, gross motor skills, and development of imagination. The creative arts help children to become curious and innovative thinkers.

Multilingual Learners Multilingual learners must process by analyzing sounds, words, and grammar. They must also process by using background knowledge to make meaning. Use the familiar animals in the story to help children with both types of processing.

Alphabet Knowledge Repetition is key to children learning new letters. Point out frequently occurring letters and expose children to printed text as much as possible. Even allowing children to explore texts independently is good exposure.

Multilingual Learners Every vocabulary card includes an Act It Out step and a photograph to help multilingual learners—indeed, all students—to access the vocabulary. Additionally, you can model and have children act out vocabulary words when possible. These multiple approaches are particularly helpful to children with limited English proficiency.

Fine Motor Skills Good motor skills are considered important for children's physical, social, and psychological development. Building with materials such as blocks and clay is not only fun but also helps to develop children's fine motor skills. Encourage them to experiment with different kinds of materials to help develop fine-motor movement and control.
Retelling a Story Research shows that retelling stories helps children with comprehension and retention of information. Add modeling and movement to make the retelling fun and even more effective!

Singing with Young Children Singing with children is fun and a powerful tool in helping to support their early brain and language development. Music introduces them to words and sound patterns. This helps develop listening and comprehension skills, which are necessary foundation for learning how to read.

Mind Builder Entrusting children with classroom jobs fosters community and develops responsibility, which leads to a sense of autonomy and pride. Letting children help create the job list and construct the anchor chart or binder is a step toward this goal (Wilson/ Responsiveclassroom.org/Classroom Jobs).

Science Terms Young children should learn basic terms and phrases used in science. The National Center for Improving Science Education has a list of concepts that young children should learn before embarking on their scientific learning. Explain how a scientific model represents other things.

Multilingual Learners The Chinese language has no plural words, so children whose home language is Chinese may have difficulties initially with changing words from singular to plural. In Chinese, a number word is placed in front of the noun and the noun remains singular. Reinforce the /s/ sound at the end of plural words so children can begin to hear it and recognize its importance in forming plural words in English.

Role Playing Role-play is an important part of child development. It builds confidence and creativity, supports physical development, and develops problem solving and communication skills. It is a fun activity that allows children to get into character and act out real-life or fictional roles.

Letter Frequency It is important to introduce and practice letters that occur frequently in English words. This will allow you to create more decodable words, and children will begin to recognize letters and sounds more readily.

Mind Builder Turn-talking is found in cultures around the world! When children learn how to take turns talking and participate in conversations with their peers, they improve their speech and language skills. Turn-talking, initiating conversation, and active listening also help establish friendships among peers (Stivers et al., 2009).

Science Providing children with songs, games, crafts, and books about the natural environment can generate excitement about science. Outdoor nature walks provide excellent support for learning about the seasons, the weather, and natural changes in the environment.

Multilingual Learners Introducing the seasons is a great way to teach related vocabulary. Provide descriptive words for each season (e.g. winter/cold/snow; spring/windy/flowers; summer/hot/beach; fall/cool/pumpkins). Display cloze sentences to increase proficiently—for example: "It is ____ in winter." (cold)

Science Learning about how animals, plants, and weather are connected helps children understand how the physical world works. Children who are attuned to the environment are more apt to respect nature and make observations and predictions. These skills will help them become better critical thinkers.

Onset and Rime Play rhyming games to help children gain awareness of onset and rime: Onset is any sound that comes before the vowel in a word and rime is the sound of the rest of the word. By exploring the relationship between rhyming words, children develop this skill, which makes them stronger readers.

Mind Builder Asking stimulating and developmentally appropriate questions can help boost the language environment. Think about extending conversations with these questions. "What are your plans for those materials? What do you think will happen next? How did you do that? What does this remind you of?" (Schwanenflugel, et al., 2005).
Digital Tools Digital tools can be a great way to expand possibilities for learning. Careful monitoring is the key to making sure children are safe as they explore digital tools.

Fairy Tales Frequent exposure to fairy tales benefits children's creative development. The tales also help develop critical thinking skills in an uncomplicated context and afford children the chance to see that bad things happen to everyone but don't necessarily lead to bad outcomes. Fairy tales display good versus evil and teach right from wrong in a manner easily seen.

Nursery Rhymes Children are already equipped with great pattern-recognition skills. When they recite nursery rhymes, they are given a great opportunity to explore the sound patterns that occur in language.

Mind Builder To ensure children take an active role in maintaining the classroom, assign jobs on a rotating basis. Jobs give children responsibilities and ownership in the classroom. Rotating jobs ensures everyone is sharing these responsibilities. Posting a list of jobs with movable names will clarify who is responsible for which job (Hayes and Creange, 2001).

Science Concepts To develop science concepts, children need to experience them in many contexts. They need to make a connection of new knowledge with what is known. To help children make these connections in different ways across the curriculum, incorporate science activities throughout the day's activities.

Multilingual Learners Remember that all children bring something to the learning environment, and that multilingual learners have knowledge, skills, competencies, and understandings that can be leveraged and built upon. The development of literacy depends on all four learning modalities. Provide opportunities for children to practice and use these modalities while learning content.

Informational Texts Exploring informational texts exposes young children to a wider range of vocabulary, enhances their language skills, and increases their knowledge of text structure and text features. Such texts also help children to develop background knowledge in many different content areas. These skills are crucial building blocks to literacy!

Multilingual Learners Allow multilingual children to share translations for words that come up in stories and conversations. Allowing children to teach others about their culture can help them feel a sense of pride in their cultural identity. It also helps to instill confidence in language skills for both native and nonnative speakers of English.

Mind Builder Learning to take initiative is a critical skill for young children to learn. It increases their willingness to try new ideas on their own and to have self-confidence. Encourage children to explore their own interests and allow children to find creative solutions to problems (Epstein, A. (2007), The Intentional Teacher).

Making Inferences Making inferences by using graphics is a useful skill for children, especially later when reading informational textbooks. Introduce children to the concept of making inferences by "reading between the lines"—using text clues. This skill allows readers to gain a deeper understanding of a narrative.

Teamwork You're in a position to lay the foundation for a skill that will be essential throughout children's lives—teamwork. Encourage teamwork through activities, games, and projects that require collaboration. Provide feedback on children's efforts at working together. Teamwork nurtures skills needed for interpersonal thinking and encourages feelings of community connection.

Emotional Development Self-awareness is difficult for young children. It's not just about recognizing feelings; self-awareness empowers children to know that how they react to those feelings affects others—for better or worse. Being self-aware makes it easier for children to empathize with others and to recognize their own strengths and weakness.

Cross-Text Connections By having children connect what they've read to other texts, they will deepen their understanding of this story. Introduce other texts that teach the same lesson. Some suggestions include Brave Little Monster, Lionheart, and I'm Not Scared.As you do, model making connections to similarities in character, plot, or other story elements.

Mind Builder Reading is one of the best ways kids can learn about their own abilities and limitations. Children can practice understanding their own feelings. This initial learning about self will develop into accepting responsibility for their actions and reactions. It can guide children to make better or different decisions in the future (Parenttoolkit.com/Self-Awareness).

Multilingual Learners Retelling stories is a great strategy for reading comprehension for multilingual learners. It helps children focus on main ideas, notice details, and follow the sequence of events that make up the plot. Retelling can be done orally, in drawing, or as reenactments. Invite children to retell the story and allow multilingual learners to reenact parts of the story to aid in comprehension and to strengthen children's literary interest.

Social Development At this stage of development, children may not know how to regard people with physical differences and may have questions. Set aside time to answer them. You have the opportunity to dispel myths about peers with disabilities and teach children that all people have many things in common.

Self-Confidence Sharing their stories will help boost self-esteem in children. It will also provide children with the mental association between trying new things and receiving praise for their efforts. Share your own childhood stories—of success and failures. Sharing will help children feel how important they are to you.

Mind Builder Patience requires self-regulation, which some children develop more easily than others. Self-regulation allows children to manage their feelings in difficult situations. Praise patient behavior in the classroom to sharpen self-awareness (Parenttoolkit.com/Self-Awareness).

Multilingual Learners Being able to create complex sentences is a great way to increase children's reading, writing, and speaking skills. As children share their conclusions, help multilingual learners create complex sentences by offering connectors they can use to extend their sentences, such as "I think the caterpillar is still impatient because ____."

Growing Up Children who are well versed in emotional literacy are happier, have better relationships, and do better academically over time. Stress the importance of emotional literacy while increasing children's confidence by pointing out how children have learned to greet each other, ask to play, manage feelings, and use empathy.

Self-to-Text Connections When children make connections between a book and their own lives, they can better relate to a character and deepen their understanding of the story line. It also bolsters reading comprehension. By inviting children to connect to the narrative, teachers help shape empathetic children and invested readers.

Compound Words Enrich children's vocabulary by pointing out compound words such as classroom, sidewalk, or bathtub. Then provide common words (such as fire, snow, air) and have children think of compound words that include them (firefighter, snowflake, airplane).

Mind Builder As children progress through preK and get ready for kindergarten, they will benefit from their teacher's guidance in terms of recognizing their abilities and limitations. Doing so in a structured environment will allow them to express pride in their abilities and begin to eliminate limitations without adding stress (Parenttoolkit.com/Self-Awareness).

Multilingual Learners Multilingual learners may enjoy adding to the discussion of cognates by sharing similarities between their native language and English. Explain that while cognates make it easier to talk to friends, we can also use nonverbal methods. Give examples of common nonverbal communications, such as waving hello and nodding in agreement.
Displaying Work When teachers display children's work, children feel that the work has value—and that they do, too. Displaying work also teaches children that hard work has value.

Poetry Exposure to poetry can open worlds to young children, and help them develop cognitively. Many poems follow a pattern of rhyme, rhythm, or repeated words. Understanding patterns will lead to better sequencing ability, which promotes the brain's ability to process and remember information.

Counting Preschoolers are still discovering the logic of the world. They may be able to count objects in one direction, but counting them in a different order can feel like a whole new task! Repetition is the key. Whenever you count a set of objects, repeat your count in at least one different order where children can clearly see your work.

Mind Builder It's important for adults to help children manage their emotions. They need to feel their emotions fully and understand that these feelings are natural. But it's equally important for children to be able to calm down. At first, children may need an adult's help in finding ways to relax. Giving suggestions like getting a book to read or moving to a calm place is the first step in guiding children to develop independent strategies (Diamond, 2013).

Friendships Children have many different ways of interacting with each other, and some might choose to play alone. They may already have friends in the class, or they may still need some encouragement from an adult to socialize. Ask children to think about who in the class they might like to talk to and share with, and guide them to do so.

Multilingual Learners Cultural standards for close friendships can vary. Pair multilingual learners with a partner who can help model what is expected of a good friend in your classroom. You might not always be able to see when a child is not sharing or taking turns the way you would like, but a partner can always be there to help nudge a child in the right direction.

Homonyms When encountering homonyms in stories, clarify that in English there are many words that look and sound the same but have different meanings. Discuss with children that to figure out which meaning of a word is being used, we pay attention to the whole sentence.

Multilingual Learners Provide plenty of opportunity for physical involvement, such as pointing to ears to explain the sense of sound and pointing to eyes to indicate the sense of sight. This reinforces vocabulary without the added complexity of needing to understand definitions as well.

Mind Builder Learning to identify different emotions and corresponding behaviors is not only critical for fostering interpersonal relationships and empathy, but also crucial in helping children understand their own behaviors. Recognizing the link between emotions and behavior helps children regulate their own emotions and control their own behaviors (Denham, Burton, 2003).

Using Ordinal Terms At this age, children are starting to tell stories and understand time. Because they understand the idea of counting, they can recall parts of a story by listing the events in order: first, second, last. Encourage them to use the same words when they are telling a story.

Counting Order In order to count a set of items, children need to know the number words in order and be able to match one number word to one item while counting. Children also need to keep track of which items have been counted. Children can use their fingers to keep track while counting, point to objects one at a time, and move objects as they're counted.

Recognizing Numerals Helping children understand and identify numerals when talking about quantities lays the groundwork for future mathematics skills. The ability of young children to compare two numerals as a symbolic representation of numbers is associated with later success in math.

Adding and Removing One Encourage children to think of the next number in a counting sequence as "one more," and the previous number as "one fewer." By implementing rational counting rather than rote counting, children begin to see that counting up is the same as adding one more, and counting down is the same as removing one—an important operations skill.

Mind Builder Help children realize that they can communicate their needs both verbally and nonverbally, and that asking politely is usually received better than demanding something. Children may not be able to identify complex needs at first. Talk about basic human needs—namely food, shelter, and clothing—and encourage children to speak up about their personal needs (Read, 1980).

Healthy Activities There are plenty of activities children can enjoy doing during just about any kind of weather. Help children think of healthy activities they can do when it is rainy, snowy, sunny, cold, hot, or windy outside. Get them excited about being able to play for a whole hour every day no matter what the weather is!

Understanding Measurement Preschoolers understand that lengths and sizes of objects vary and can be compared. Children start by informally comparing the lengths, heights, and sizes of objects and people around them. Help children develop this skill by using measurement vocabulary and asking children to measure using nonstandard units of measurement.

Mind Builder Although it may be difficult for children to articulate their understanding of thinking symbolically, they already practice this skill multiple times daily. Even if they can't explain it, children understand that numbers are symbolic representations of actual quantities, letters represent spoken language, and maps represent places (Ryan/Redleafpress.org, 2008).

Comparing Measurements At this age, children start to understand that measurements can be used to compare two or more objects or people. Have children compare their heights with the heights of their friends. Line up by shortest to tallest and tallest to shortest, or compare how long some pencils are. Encourage children to arrange things in size order frequently.

Collecting and Organizing Data Graphic representations are a powerful way for children to collect, organize, and understand data. Although the concept of data is abstract, children are able to interpret graphic representations of data and develop an understanding of the presented information. An added bonus of graphing is that it is fun for children!

Comparing Measurements Encourage children to use playtime to reinforce measurement concepts. Experiment on the seesaw by asking different children to try to balance it. Encourage children to make predictions before the children sit on the seesaw. Guide children to compare their predictions to the outcome. Ask them to share their conclusions with the group.

Mind Builder Children are transitioning from playing alone or in parallel to engaging with others. Model for children how to join a group by helping them through the process. Ask the question for them, "May I play, too?" Remind them what the group's goal is so they can adopt the same goal in their play (LeBlanc/OCW.UMB.edu, 1989).

Operations PreK children can begin to understand that adding or taking away one item from a set changes the total by one. You can introduce card and board games like Go Fish or Chutes and Ladders to reinforce the concept of adding to or taking away from a set.

Weight Affects Movement When discussing the concept of weight, point out that the more weight an object has, the more difficult it is to lift; the less weight an object has, the easier it is to lift. Use measurement tools such as balance scales to experiment with weight. Reinforce the use of the terms more than, less than, and equal to. Add different numbers of items or amounts of material to each side of the scale to see changes in movement.

Counting Remind children that they can count anything, anytime! Help children hone their counting skills by incorporating counting into activities and situations throughout the day. Whenever you use a group of items, ask a volunteer to count the number of objects and tell the class how many objects there are in all.

Mind Builder Asking questions is a key way children learn. Encourage them to ask questions for both of these reasons: to learn something they don't yet know, e.g., "What is the biggest animal in the world?", and to learn more about something they already know a little about, e.g., "If whales are so big, how do they get enough food?" ("Prekindergarten Guidelines," 2015).

Subtraction Subtraction poses a unique challenge because some children may struggle with the concept of being left with a lesser number or amount than they started with. You can help them internalize this concept by always phrasing a subtraction question the same way: "How many do you have left?" or "What are you left with?"

Recognizing Patterns Help children recognize patterns in math by showing them that there are patterns all around them. Color and shape patterns are often visible on clothing. Environmental patterns are present in rows of houses and windows in a building. Even your classroom has patterns everywhere! Challenge children to identify patterns they see in the room.
Multilingual Learners Use visual aids to help multilingual children strengthen their ability to recognize numbers. Show children the corresponding number cards as you say each number aloud.

Measurement Take advantage of everyday occurrences to teach vocabulary terms related to measurement. Using more precise terms such as tall or long instead of big can help children understand basic amounts and sizes.

Mind Builder Reframing the narrative in order to empower or motivate oneself is an important skill in the emotional development of children. Adults can model for children how to see a situation in a new and positive way ("You're not first in line, but you get to stand next to your friend!") in order to help them internalize this behavior (Hall, Kordich, Pearson, 2003).

Subitizing Once children are familiar with the one-to-one correspondence of numbers, they will be able to look at small groups of objects, and understand intuitively what, for example, "three" looks like without having to count "one, two, three." Practicing this skill will increase a child's confidence in counting to higher numbers as well as in performing addition.

Trying to Help Others Doing something for someone to try to make things better or easier is an important part of children's social development. Discussing caring for pets and animals can help children develop these skills. Helping others can also include bringing an upset peer his or her favorite stuffed animal or blanket (Denham and Burton, 2003).

The 1-2-3 of Counting In order to count a set of items, children need to know the number words in order, match each number word to one item while counting, and be able to keep track of which items have been counted. When you count with children, keep a finger on each item as it is counted to demonstrate clearly how to count accurately.

Mind Builder Impulse control is an important part of acting responsibly toward ourselves and others. Support children's impulse control by looking for teachable moments in everyday life. When children find ways to stop and think about their actions, they build the executive function skills needed to develop logical thinking and responsibility (Diamond, 2006).

Location Words Practicing with location words not only develops spatial awareness, but also prepares children to follow directions later in life. In kindergarten classrooms, children are often told to put things under a table or stand behind a line. If children do not know directional language, misunderstandings can lead to perceived behavior issues.

Multilingual Learners Location words, prepositions, can be particularly difficult for multilingual learners to grasp. Help children visualize the meanings of location words by drawing a picture that represents each concept. For example, draw a bird under a tree. Then, draw the bird flying above the tree. Connect the words to the illustrations by pointing to each as you discuss.

Working Memory The ability to mentally hold and use information is a critical preschool skill. Working memory skills predict math and reading scores, and they are more strongly associated with school readiness than IQ! An essential way to teach these skills is through daily play. This way, children are continually supported and challenged as they progress.

Classification Children naturally sort objects in their world into categories: shiny and dull, markers and crayons, silly and not silly. Guide children to sort items in a collection and help them name the categories. Encourage children to sort and re-sort the same set of objects by different attributes.

Mind Builder Showing curiosity is essential to lifelong learning. Adults can support children's curiosity by looking for teachable moments in everyday life. Foster children's curiosity by helping them engage with the math in their world. Guide them to think mathematically about everyday activities: "Which block is heavier? Which bowl has more cereal?" (Yale, 2002).

Equal Groups Dividing objects into equal groups is essential to the idea of sharing, a skill most children are learning and practicing regularly in PreK. Encourage families to talk about separating objects into equal groups to make sure each group has a "fair share."

Multilingual Learners Help children build language skills by providing a simple sentence frame. For example, say "The horse has _____ feet" while pointing to the horse. Scaffold children's responses by having them show the number on their fingers, say one word, or repeat the sentence frame.

Recognizing Patterns Children can recognize, create, and copy simple patterns on their own, even before they know the term pattern. To identify and extend more-complex patterns, children do best with the guidance of an adult who helps them see and understand the patterns.

Mind Builder Positive interactions can have a strong impact on educational outcomes. Children can form a base for having positive interactions by trying to understand situations they observe. Encourage children to build a base for engaging with adults and peers by having them start by asking questions like "Why is that child doing that?" (Zigler, Gilliam, Jones, 2006).

Operations Children can build off their foundational understanding of counting by adding or taking away one from a small group. Help supplement children's natural ability to add and subtract by practicing increasing and decreasing numbers of items by one throughout the day.

Body Awareness Singing songs that incorporate movement help children gain a better awareness of what their body can do and how it works. Play games that challenge them to try movements like touching their right hand to their left knee.

Multilingual Learners Help multilingual learners feel more comfortable in the class and help other children connect with different cultures and languages by making some activities a "two-way street." When teaching about music, invite multilingual learners to share a song from their home culture and have the class sing it together.

Counting Syllables Understanding that large words can be broken down into smaller parts, or syllables, can make it easier for children to learn how to read and write. One way to find syllables in words is by clapping. For example, you may say market together and clap on each syllable. Challenge students to count the syllables in other familiar words, such as banana or watermelon.

Addition and Subtraction At this early stage, it's important to focus on teaching children the basic concepts of addition and subtraction: putting together and taking away. Telling stories and using concrete objects to show numbers being added or taken away is a great way to encourage children to start using these concepts in the real world.

Eating Healthy Foods What children hear and think about eating healthy when they are young can greatly affect how they feel about themselves and their diet later on in life. Help promote healthy eating thoughts and habits by being a role model. Talk about the healthy foods you like to eat and what you find tasty about them.

Rote Counting Rote counting is the base skill of all math concepts. Before you can add or subtract, you must know what the numbers are! Practice is key, especially for the teen numbers, as they do not follow the common pattern of number names (seven-teen, rather than ten-seven). Try to find opportunities to practice numbers 10–20 as often as you can.

Mind Builder It is crucial for young children to develop an "environment of relationships." Positive peer-to-peer and adult-to-child interactions lay the foundation for both academic success and mental health. Start by helping children refer to each other and you by name, and to notice each other's defining traits and features. Point out when someone is absent (NSCDC, 2004).

Counting Order One important principle of counting "how many" items is that the order in which items are counted is irrelevant. Help children understand that objects can be counted left to right, right to left, or randomly, and the same number will be reached as long as every object in the set is given one count. Seeing this in practice reinforces the concept.

Multilingual Learners Hand-washing methods and beliefs can vary greatly among different cultures. In Hindu culture, ash or mud is used in place of soap and has been proven to be just as effective. In Ghana, visitors traditionally wash their faces and hands before entering a home. Invite children to share any hand-washing habits they have been taught by their families.

Dental Health Although baby teeth fall out and are replaced by adult teeth, tooth decay in baby teeth can still lead to future dental problems. Preschoolers have a limited ability to take care of their own teeth, but you can coach them to create healthy habits and remind families to make brushing teeth part of their daily routine.

Spatial Sense Children develop an understanding of spatial sense by using positional words and phrases, such as beside, up, and down. Practicing with these words develops spatial awareness. Connect the positional words in the book to real life examples by using the same phrases throughout the day.

Mind Builder Boundaries are an important part of emotional development. It starts with children's awareness of where their bodies are in relation to other children. Children can then relate how they feel about their personal space to how others feel about their personal space, and why boundaries are important (Epstein, 2007, pp. 100–103).

Being Safe Safety drills can be worrying for many children. Help children cope by providing context (fires rarely happen) and showing patterns of behavior (practicing fire drills). Role-playing situations, like fire drills, give children situational context and shows them what to expect. It may also be helpful to explain the unlikeliness of a real emergency.

Graphing Children first learn about classification by sorting. Graphing allows for children to begin more complex classification. Simple bar graphs can help children to interact with visual information, work together, and learn from each other.

Multilingual Learners Visual support and gestures can help multilingual learners become comfortable with location terms. Singing and moving to action songs like "The Hokey Pokey" and pointing out real-world examples in context can help support children's acquisition of words while fostering spatial sense.

Multilingual Learners Children have varied experiences with fairy tales. Classic fairy tales such as Cinderella are told differently in different cultures. And of course, every culture has its own traditional stories! Invite children to describe and even retell the tales they name, as best as they can. Encourage them to act out or draw their favorite scenes in centers.

Mind Builder Understanding that other people have different feelings and perspectives helps children see how their actions can affect others. Remind children that even if two people disagree, both perspectives can be valid. Remember, too, that perspective can affect relative size: A shirt that is too small on you may be too big for someone else (Read et al., 1980).

Recognizing Patterns Patterns are arrangements of things that repeat in a logical way. They can be made with colors, shapes, sounds, or numbers. They can even be found in the events in a book! Patterns are important for preschoolers, because they help them to predict what will happen next. A story like Goldilocks offeres a wonderful opportunity to point out patterns that may help children make predictions.

Comparing Size Children compare size all the time, often without knowing it—they discuss portions of food, compare sizes of toys, and measure their own heights against the heights of their friends. It is important to help children develop a conscious awareness of measurement with formal words (large, small, tall, short, as well as larger/est, smaller/est, taller/est, shorter/est). Demonstrate the meanings of these words by using them in context.

Understanding Capacity Preschoolers may know that a small container holds less than a large one. It will take time for them to understand that containers that are tall and thin may hold the same amount as containers that are short and wide. Encourage children to use containers of many different sizes and shapes as they play.

Naming and Describing Shapes Giving children the proper mathematical vocabulary lays essential groundwork for their long-term understanding of math. Teaching children the names of shapes and helping them become comfortable identifying both the names and the qualities of shapes is key in preparing them for more advanced geometry.

Mind Builder Showing respect by inviting someone you don't know to join you is an essential lifelong skill. Support children's ability to initiate play and join in groups already playing by looking for teachable moments when children are at play. Helping children develop the ability to make friends is a gift that can last a lifetime (Encourageplay.com/Play and Social Skills).

Making Mistakes Some children may be sensitive about making mistakes and possible repercussions. Reinforce that mistakes can happen and that you are there to help. Guide children to notice that we can all learn and grow from our mistakes.

Finding Shapes All Around Us You can help children understand geometry by encouraging them to notice the geometric shapes all around them. By pointing out shapes both in images in the book and in the real world, you help them become more familiar with shapes and more enthusiastic about learning geometry.

Geometry Guided play with Pattern Blocks can help children attain geometric understanding and introduce them to the vocabulary of geometry. Give children opportunities to sort and name shapes and to create new shapes by combining other shapes.

Mind Builder A classroom environment that allows for failure and occasional child choice is one that will help children develop initiative and problem-solving skills. Creative play stations and opportunities to choose among activities are essential for developing this skill, which is critical for success in school and in life (physicianscenter.org/parents).

Multilingual Learners The English words triangle (triángulo), circle (circulo), and pyramid (pirámide) have close Spanish equivalents, but square (cuadrado) does not. Children will be expected to know some basic shapes by kindergarten, so give all children ample time to manipulate and name Pattern Blocks or other shape manipulatives.

Teamwork Having children work collaboratively helps promote social development, building skills in communication and problem solving. To work cooperatively, children must learn to listen to each other and to exchange ideas. Offer frequent opportunities for partner work.

Perseverance Overcoming obstacles and working toward a goal is hard for grown-ups, let alone young children. Help children learn perseverance by breaking down tasks into steps, by standing back rather than taking over, and by praising their hard work and problem solving rather than their innate talent or intelligence.

Concrete and Pictorial Models Using concrete materials or pictorial models creates a tangible understanding of an abstract concept, such as math. Models can be used to help children add and subtract numbers using objects such as counters. By using concrete or pictorial models, children start to develop an understanding of abstract mathematical concepts.

Solving Problems Provide children with language they could use to solve problems. Guide children to role-play how they would respond if someone grabbed a toy from them: "Instead of getting upset, you could calmly say, 'I am playing with that.'" Encourage children to engage in conflict resolution like this without adult help.

Multilingual Learners Most communication is nonverbal. Exaggerating nonverbal cues as you teach vocabulary is a way to help multilingual learners. For example, when you teach heavy, weigh your arms down and sag as you say the word. As you discuss which items are heavy, repeat these nonverbal cues.

Vocabulary Development Expanding children's vocabulary with academic terms opens up possibilities to children both in school and outside. Encourage children to use academic vocabulary they have learned throughout the day and in different contexts. Remind them that when they hear terms they do not know, they can ask what the words mean, including asking outside of school.

Measurement Preschool children mostly think of weight informally: they estimate which of two objects is harder to push and pull, they ask themselves which object feels heavier in their hands, and, often, they guess by simply looking at the objects. When discussing the weights of objects, remind children that weight is determined by both material and size.

Fatigue Yawning in class is natural, but in some cases children become tired from the effort it takes to stay focused. Give these children multiple opportunities to get up and move. Physical activity helps children stay more alert and engaged.

Strengthening Memory One way to help children strengthen their working memory is to suggest they form a mental picture of what they've heard or seen or what they're trying to remember. For example, if you're talking about the numbers two and three, suggest that the child "see" two suns or three moons (ADD Resource Center, 2017).

Time Duration is tricky for preschoolers. Children may understand that an event happened in the past but may use yesterday to indicate two days (or even two months) ago. Help children understand the concept of a long time by explaining time in context. For example, explain that eating lunch usually takes longer than eating a snack.

Understanding Night and Day You can start to build on children's understanding of day and night with a very brief science lesson. Explain that the Earth is always turning. When one side faces toward the Sun, the other side faces away from the Sun. For the side facing the Sun, it is day. For the side facing away from the Sun, it is night. Use a ball to help children visualize the basic idea.

Ordinal Terms Knowing ordinal terms (first, second, third, ...) allows children to understand and communicate the orders or placements of people or things. The ordinals first, second, and third are different from the cardinal numbers one, two, and three, so children often need to learn and practice these terms separately.

Using Imagination When children use their imagination, they practice expressing themselves (both verbally and nonverbally), interacting, reacting, and trying out different roles. Using their imaginations and trying new ways of doing things helps children develop critical thinking skills and encourages creative problem solving (www.brighthorizons.com/family-resources).

Spatial Language Using spatial language to describe position and location—for example, near, under, over—helps children better describe their environment and encourages spatial problem-solving. You can support spatial language when asking children to put things away in the classroom by being as specific as possible ("put this on top of the shelf, next to the pens").

The Seasons Learning about the four seasons helps children understand how time passes and how things change. Observation is an important part of learning about the seasons, including outside exploration and discussion. Help children make connections between the classroom and the world outdoors. While outside, children can make note of changes they see and then draw pictures of their observations in science journals.

Multilingual Learners Help multilingual learners feel more confident by displaying words and phrases in their home languages. This will help them communicate their thoughts and feelings more easily. For math concepts, you can write out and display the number words, as well as some basic position words, in the child's home language.

Sentence Structure Children develop proper sentence structure mainly through repetition. As you read, have children repeat possessive sentences and pronouns after you: "This is Lola's garden. She planted it." Encourage children to answer questions in complete sentences, pausing to model correct subject-verb agreement and plurals when necessary.

Mind Builder Empathy is an important step in children's ability to help others. Children need to be able to identify that others need help and know what kind of help others need. As you read, help children find hints as to when characters may be sad or struggling to do something alone. Model thinking aloud about what you could do to help (Denham, 2003).

Measurement Children develop an understanding of measurement by using words that describe size, such as big, small, tall, and short. Practicing with these words builds an awareness that different items have different dimensions. Have children find and describe different-sized items in books as well as in real life.

Scientific Thinking PreK children are already scientific thinkers. They perform their own experiments, like testing which way a ball will roll or how much water can fill a cup. Part of scientific thinking is making predictions. You may wish to do a class planting project. Invite children to predict what will happen each day as the seedlings develop. Encourage them to check for changes and discuss what they see.

Multilingual Learners Past-tense verbs can be tricky for multilingual learners, particularly when the verbs are irregular. Model several sentences before asking children to contribute their own, using words that clearly denote time: "Last year, we planted seeds." Repeat irregular past-tense verbs often to help children become familiar with them: "A plant grew from the seed we planted."

Shapes Learning about shapes is the first way children begin to explore geometry. Young children observe that shapes can be combined and broken down to make new shapes (for example, two squares combine to become a rectangle). This helps them begin to see the relationship between two- and three-dimensional shapes.

Mind Builder Preschoolers are usually eager to follow daily routines. Most young children appreciate the structure of classroom rules because predictable rules and routines let them know what to expect throughout the day. Because they are so reliant on routines, children sometimes get frustrated or angry when an adult deviates from the routine (Miller, Scholastic.com).

Solid Shapes Clay can be a helpful way to teach three-dimensional shapes to children who may have trouble understanding that flat two-dimensional shapes make up the sides of three-dimensional shapes. Children can use shape cookie cutters to make flat shapes and then join them together to create a three-dimensional shape, like a box or a can.

Protecting the Earth If children learn to appreciate the Earth at a young age, they are more likely to work to protect it in the future. Young children begin learning empathy for the people around them during preschool. By teaching them about protecting the Earth, they can learn to extend their empathy to animals, plants, and the environment.

Multilingual Learners Having consistent routines in the classroom can help multilingual learners improve their language skills. If children know which activities take place in each area of the classroom, they can begin to use physical and visual cues to know what to do and how to behave in that area each day.

Multilingual Learners Children with a different home language can benefit from multiple pre-reading activities, including pre-teaching relevant vocabulary and having children make predictions about the story. After reading, return to their predictions and determine if they were accurate.

Mind Builder As children become more aware of other people, they will start to recognize that others are sad or upset. Help children learn to express their concern directly to that person. Model words that they can use to communicate their concern. Explain that they might also offer physical comfort, such as a hug, if the friend agrees to it (Denham and Burton, 2003).

Subitizing Consistent practice of both perceptual and conceptual subitizing can boost children's later mathematics skills. Perceptual subitizing is the ability to recognize the number of items in a group without counting. Conceptual subitizing is the ability to add together the groupings from their first perceptions.

Digital Tools Digital tools can complement academic instruction in the classroom when they are used appropriately. Allow children to explore devices containing age-appropriate interactive media to reinforce what you are teaching in class.

Literacy Help children pre-read the book by showing the pictures before reading aloud the text. Talk with children about what they expect the text will say and the clues they used to come to these conclusions. To review how the pictures relate to the story, ask children to say what is shown in the pictures.

Print Concepts Reading with an adult who models the reading process is crucial in building children's early literacy. Children learn that text has meaning by watching and listening as someone reads it aloud. As you read aloud important words in texts, such as number words and key vocabulary, run your finger below the word to show where and how you are reading the letters.

Mind Builder Playing together may look different for children at this age depending on the stage of development. For younger preschoolers, parallel (playing alongside another child) and associative (playing the same game, but without interacting) play may be more common than directly joining a group. Encourage and praise all levels of peer play (Guralnick, 1993).

Spatial Sense Preschoolers tend to best understand spatial awareness by moving their own bodies, such as by standing up and sitting down. However, it's important for children to explore spatial concepts in multiple ways. Provide many opportunities for children to use location words, from giving directions to experimenting with classroom objects.

Multilingual Learners Colloquial phrases and idioms can be confusing to children whose home language is not English. As you come across idiomatic phrases, be sure to take time to explain their meanings. You may want to pair multilingual children with a classmate who can explain what is meant, which will also help establish relationships and model teamwork.

Cardinality As children age, they begin to understand that numbers can represent quantities. Through repetition, they count objects and hear that the last number counted is the number of objects in that group. This is called cardinality. Reinforce the concept by pointing to objects as they are counted, showing one-to-one correspondence.

Using a Ruler Children have practiced comparing heights and lengths informally by sight and by nonstandard units. Learning to use a ruler is the next step! Although children are unlikely to correctly measure using a ruler, encourage them to practice lining up an object with the end of the ruler and noting what number it reaches.

Mind Builder For preschoolers, talking and sharing often starts with recalling a recent event, such as what they did with their families over the weekend. It grows over time to sharing like interests with classmates. Model talking and sharing about your own experiences and preferences whenever possible (Read & Patterson, 1980).

Sentence Structure You have been speaking with children and adding to their vocabulary all year. You naturally support them in speaking in longer, more creative sentences. Encourage children to extend their phrases by modeling how to do that. If a child says, "I like it," you can respond, "I like that red toy, too, because it's so big and shiny!"

Multilingual Learners While many children will start to use more complex sentences in preK, multilingual learners might still use one-word answers as they continue to explore a new language. Encourage children to expand their sentences using favorite or familiar topics. Provide frames for complex sentences and guide children to use the frames to extend their thoughts.

Classification Graphing data that children are invested in increases their interest in classification and in math as a whole. For example, they may vote on favorite characters from a book and compare the results on a bar graph you create. Or they can compare their own heights, with each child's height as its own bar. Invite children to help you come up with other topics that could be easily graphed.

Multilingual Learners Multilingual learners may find it difficult to count backward. Not only do they have to remember the names of the numbers in a new language, but they have to remember them in reverse order! Display a number line or the digits 0–10 in the classroom and refer to them to help children visualize which number comes before and after.

Measuring Time At this stage, children are aware of past, present, and future. However, they are likely to have difficulty measuring time formally. Point to a clock or calendar to help children visualize the passage of time as you discuss hours and days. Will that happen in the future, or a time after now? We can use a calendar to measure how long that will be.

Careers Talking with children about what they want to be when they grow up, even at this young age, helps them start to think about what they are good at and enjoy doing. Invite children to name jobs that family members have, and use that as a springboard for brainstorming a list of various occupations and careers.

entorno del salón de clases Tener algunos objetos de los niños en el salón de clases ayudará a la transición entre el hogar y el prekínder. Objetos como fotos de la familia, o su libro favorito, les servirán para adaptarse mejor al nuevo entorno. Comunicarles el horario de las actividades y mantenerlo en un lugar visible ayudará a que se sientan cómodos.

Mind Builder Construir y mantener buenas relaciones es clave en el desarrollo social, y debe ser motivo de enfoque todo el año. Los niños pueden aprender a participar de relaciones confiables con usted, otros adultos y sus compañeros. Es importante realizar actividades durante el día que ayuden a los niños a crear empatía hacia los demás. (Boyarshinov/frogstreet.com)

escuchar Escuchar y recordar son las dos primeras habilidades fundamentales para la comprensión y la lectoescritura en los niños. Asegúrese de que los niños prestan atención a lo que usted y los demás dicen. Leer en voz alta cada día motiva a los niños a interesarse por las historias de los personajes, las suyas propias y las de los demás.

estudios sociales Personas de diferentes partes del mundo tienen nombres diferentes, viven en lugares diferentes y poseen tradiciones diferentes. Enfatice la importancia de aceptar y respetar las diferencias entre personas de todas partes del mundo.

desarrollo socioemocional Es fácil observar el desarrollo físico de los niños a esta edad, ya que los vemos cada vez más altos, más grandes y más fuertes. Es más difícil evaluar su desarrollo socioemocional, pero es importante hacerlo. Preste atención especial a la comprensión que demuestran los niños de los sentimientos propios, así como los de los demás.

Mind Builder Aprender a identificar todos los sentimientos de manera positiva ayuda a los niños a desarrollar las habilidades que necesitan para convertirse en niños y adultos sanos y bien adaptados. Saber identificar los sentimientos de los demás no solo les ayuda a entender sus propias emociones, sino también a desarrollar empatía y amistades fuertes.

alumnos multilingües Aunque los estudiantes multilingües puedan tener dificultades con el idioma, las emociones humanas son universales. Comentarlas puede dar pie a temas que de otra manera serían difíciles de abordar. Sin embargo, es importante mostrar sensibilidad ante las diferencias culturales y emocionales que existen entre las personas.

desarrollo del vocabulario El mayor desarrollo de vocabulario ocurre durante los años preescolares. Si bien los sentimientos tienen un fuerte componente no verbal, los niños deben aprender las palabras que usarán para hablar correctamente y con compasión sobre sus sentimientos.

hábitos saludables Así como el ejercicio físico y la nutrición son importantes para la vida saludable de los niños pequeños, también lo es aprender cómo acceder, comprender y manejar sus sentimientos. Les será muy útil desarrollar una relación saludable con sus sentimientos.

desarrollo socioemocional Los niños necesitan practicar destrezas sociales y emocionales en la clase, al jugar y en el hogar. Esta semana, al hablar sobre las familias, podrá evaluar las habilidades sociales y emocionales de los niños a medida que interactúan con usted y con otros niños. Observe qué áreas de la vida familiar requieren más conciencia.

alumnos multilingües Las clases son cada vez más diversas y buscan crear un entorno seguro y enriquecedor. Compartir libros de varias culturas del mundo demuestra que los niños se benefician al conocer otros idiomas y culturas. Si haya en un cuento palabras escritas en otros idiomas, pida a los niños que digan esas palabras en su lengua materna.

conexión entre los textos Para los preescolares, la lectura cobra vida cuando ven cómo las ideas y los temas de una lectura en voz alta se relacionan con otros libros y con sus vidas. Asegúrese de tener para los niños libros sobre familias, niños de edad preescolar, mascotas, la escuela, la comida, las estaciones del año y otros temas que se pueden relacionar con sus vidas.

HEADER: Relacionar con el área de contenido
TEXT: relacionar con el área de contenido Mientras leemos y releemos libros con niños, podemos buscar oportunidades de aprendizaje en conjunto. Un libro sobre la amistad puede también incluir información sobre las estaciones del año, las necesidades de los seres vivos, las partes de una casa y más. Considere estimular los intereses de los niños y despertar su amor por el aprendizaje.

Mind Builder Iniciar y participar en juegos es una habilidad clave para el desarrollo social de los niños pequeños. Mientras juegan, aprenden habilidades importantes que usarán el resto de sus vidas: resolver problemas, crear y asumir riesgos, etc. Ayudarlos a aprender el lenguaje para iniciar y participar en juegos los prepara para el éxito. (Pathways.org/six stages)

alumnos multilingües Las palabras que comparten la misma morfología o raíz se conocen como cognados. Por ejemplo, la palabra en inglés delicious y la palabra en español delicioso son cognados. Brindar a los alumnos multilingües la oportunidad de reconocer y hablar sobre cognados ayuda a fortalecer sus habilidades en ambos idiomas.

desarrollo socioemocional Es importante que los niños pequeños se sientan seguros, valorados y protegidos. Centrar su atención en cómo se desarrollan las amistades entre los personajes ficticios y en sus vidas reales desempeñará un papel vital durante este período crítico de crecimiento socioemocional.

habilidades de motricidad gruesa Los niños pequeños necesitan jugar varias horas al día para desarrollar cuerpos fuertes. Anímelos a ejercitar sus cuerpos mientras aprenden sobre la amistad. Estimúlelos a realizar movimientos largos en su interacción con otros niños y movimientos más cortos mientras escuchan la lectura, cantan o realizan actividades en el salón de clase.

alumnos multilingües Los niños pequeños que están aprendiendo más de un idioma obtienen muchos beneficios cognitivos y sociales a largo plazo. Cree un ambiente de aprendizaje donde los niños puedan usar el inglés y su idioma materno. Explíqueles a los padres que el uso de otro idioma no retrasará el crecimiento de sus hijos en inglés.

Mind Builder La autoconciencia es una habilidad que ayudará a los niños a aprender sobre sí mismos y sus sentimientos. Use palabras de sentimiento como orgulloso y frustrado para ayudar a los niños a reconocer sus propios sentimientos.

conversación Comience conversaciones con preguntas sobre lo que están haciendo los niños ("¿En qué estás trabajando?"), pidiendo explicaciones ("¿Por qué crees que pasa?"), pidiéndoles que hagan predicciones ("¿Qué crees que pasará ahora?") y que asocien lo que leen con sus propias vidas ("¿Alguna vez has hecho eso?").

alumnos multilingües Anime a los niños a describir lo que ven en el salón. El entorno preescolar puede ser el primer entorno social desconocido que enfrentan los alumnos multilingües. Pueden tener dificultades para comunicarse, seguir instrucciones y expresar ideas y sentimientos. Alentar a los niños a compartir lo que ven fomentará la conversación libre.

volver a narrar un cuento Aprender a volver a narrar un cuento es una habilidad que ayudará a los niños con la comprensión lectora posterior. Pídales que hablen sobre lo que sucedió en la historia, los personajes, qué dijeron e hicieron y a dónde fueron. Pueden volver a narrar el cuento con un dibujo de una parte de la historia.

alumnos multilingües Lo que los niños aprenden en un idioma se transferirá a otros idiomas de forma natural. Por ejemplo, una vez que los niños aprenden sobre la comunidad en su idioma materno, no necesitan volver a aprender los mismos conceptos en español. Simplemente necesitan aprender el vocabulario correspondiente en español.

Mind Builder La habilidad del pensamiento flexible nos permite aplicar diferentes reglas en diferentes situaciones. Lo usamos cuando probamos un nuevo alimento, vamos a un nuevo lugar, clasificamos las cosas de una manera nueva y más. No nacemos con esta habilidad, pero ¡todos tenemos la capacidad de practicarla y mejorarla en cualquier etapa de la vida!

andamiaje Haga preguntas a los niños para ayudarlos a avanzar en su aprendizaje. Estimule a los niños con cuidado, para que avancen poco a poco; con ello experimentarán la sensación de crecimiento y logro sin sentirse abrumados. Diferencie sus preguntas, si es necesario, para ayudar a todos los niños a seguir creciendo y aprendiendo.

aprender sobre iguales y diferentes Los niños en edad preescolar pueden entender si los objetos son iguales o diferentes. Comience con cosas concretas. Por ejemplo, señale si varios niños usan una camisa del mismo color. Luego, señale diferentes colores de camisa. Con el tiempo podrá comparar conceptos más abstractos como, por ejemplo, los intereses.

la investigación científica Fomente la curiosidad de los niños sobre el mundo natural creando un ambiente que estimule la curiosidad, la observación y la indagación. Anímelos a observar, preguntar, dibujar y hablar sobre lo que ven. Ponga el foco de atención en lo que los niños observan directamente y en las plantas y los animales del entorno en el que viven.

Mind Builder Los libros que emplean la rima y la repetición ayudan a los niños a aprender cómo hacer predicciones. También, ayudan a los niños a practicar el uso de estrategias de comprensión, como escuchar y recordar, usar conocimientos previos, hacer inferencias, asociar, sacar conclusiones y hacer preguntas.

Mind Builder En preescolar, los niños comienzan a darse cuenta de que todos tenemos sentimientos y experiencias diferentes. Comienzan a preocuparse por los demás, pero pueden seguir confundiendo sus propios sentimientos con los de otros. Puede ayudarles hablando sobre sus sentimientos y los sentimientos de los personajes de los libros.

estudios sociales Los niños en edad preescolar aprenden conceptos de estudios sociales al observar y conversar sobre su entorno: sus hogares, los parques infantiles, las tiendas, las bibliotecas, las escuelas, las estaciones de bomberos y los bancos. Anime a los niños a comparar su vecindario con los de los libros, tomando en cuenta las semejanzas y diferencias.

vocabulario sofisticado Una manera clave de predecir el rendimiento académico es el vocabulario. Desarrollar el conocimiento sobre las palabras sofisticadas es fundamental para que el niño tenga éxito en la escuela y en la vida. A los niños les gusta aprender "palabras largas". Usar palabras como apetecible, exquisito y exclamó les será útil en la vida diaria.

manejar la decepción Aprender a manejar la decepción ayuda a los niños a desarrollar habilidades de superación y resiliencia emocional. Guíelos identificando sus propias emociones (frustración, cansancio, etc.) y ayudándolos a identificar y describir las de ellos. Enséñelos a respirar profundamente cuando se sientan tristes o decepcionados.

Mind Builder Puede enseñar a los niños a reconocer su propia perspectiva y la de los demás enfatizando en la perspectiva de un personaje en textos leídos en voz alta. Ayude a los niños a aprender a reconocer la perspectiva de un personaje, o cómo piensa y siente, y compararla con su propia perspectiva.

alumnos multilingües Ayude a los niños a expresar sus sentimientos en español con palabras como decepcionado, cómodo, relajado, feliz, triste, preocupado, confundido, apenado y avergonzado. Los preescolares multilingües están aprendiendo estas palabras en su lengua materna también.

alumnos multilingües La mayoría de los alumnos multilingües conocerán en su lengua materna los nombres de muchas cosas familiares, como por ejemplo, los vehículos: el automóvil, el barco, el autobús y el avión. Anímelos a enseñarle al resto de la clase el nombre de dos vehículos en su lengua materna.

HEADER: Aprender sobre las partes de los animales
TEXT: aprender sobre las partes de los animales Cuando la clase está estudiando sobre animales, anime a los niños a hablar sobre las partes del cuerpo de diferentes animales, como la trompa del elefante. Pídales que nombren otras partes, como alas, picos, garras, cuernos, pieles, plumas, patas, escamas, colas y aletas. Verifique su comprensión de cada parte. Anímelos a clasificar los animales según las diferentes partes del cuerpo.

desarrollo del vocabulario Los niños en edad preescolar usan sus sentidos para explorar materiales, posiciones y movimientos. Necesitan vocabulario para expresar sus descubrimientos sobre la naturaleza, el movimiento, el clima, la energía y el medio ambiente. Fomente el lenguaje científico mientras participan en las conversaciones en clase.

Mind Builder Hacer y responder preguntas son habilidades clave de la función ejecutiva que se utilizan para aprender y compartir cuando nos comunicamos con otros. Practicamos esta habilidad cuando preguntamos quién, qué, cuándo, por qué, dónde y cómo. También la usamos cuando hacemos preguntas de seguimiento relacionadas con una pregunta original.

alumnos multilingües Presentar a los niños palabras que describen sabores, olores, formas, sonidos y materiales es una gran forma de ampliar su vocabulario en inglés. Es posible que ya conozcan algunos conceptos, como salado, en su lengua materna y solo necesiten una etiqueta en inglés. Otros conceptos, como amargo, pueden ser nuevos.

diagramas La habilidad de comprender el significado de las imágenes es una habilidad de desarrollo para preescolares. Apoye los diferentes niveles de habilidad para ver el propósito y el significado en las flechas, los círculos separados y las imágenes que ilustran los sentidos del niño. Esta habilidad beneficiará a los niños mientras avanzan hacia la lectoescritura.

desarrollo del vocabulario El vocabulario de los niños en el preescolar es el mejor indicador del nivel de su capacidad lectora para el grado 3. La repetición del vocabulario y oír las palabras en una variedad de contextos son vitales para que las internalicen. Mantenga una lista del vocabulario enseñado y repase cada día algunas de esas palabras.

Mind Builder Es importante ayudar a los niños, desde una edad muy temprana, a establecer objetivos y descubrir cómo lograrlos. Esto puede ayudarlos a desarrollar una actitud positiva y confiada para el resto de sus vidas. Anime a los más chicos a pensar en un objetivo pequeño y descubrir los pasos que deben seguir para lograrlo.

alumnos multilingües Las exploraciones del área de contenido pueden proporcionar oportunidades divertidas y emocionantes para que los estudiantes multilingües descubran y utilicen sus habilidades lingüísticas.
